title: Automation and the Labor Market: Evidence from Technological Change in Colombia, 2009-2017
affiliations: Universidad del Rosario Bogota- Colombia

detail.title: Automation and the Labor Market: Evidence from Technological Change in Colombia, 2009-2017
detail.abstract: This paper studies differences in the labor markets for occupations with different automation risk, and how actual automation may induce changes in wages and employment. Using data from Colombia between 2009 and 2017, we compute wage disparities by automation risk. We find that 62% of the occupied people in Colombia are at high-risk of automation. In the same way, we find that 71% of informal workers are at high-risk, while 56% of formal workers are. The wage return to education are highest in the less automatable occupations. We then look at the effects of actual education, measured by ICT investment. On wages and employment, automation increases employment, decreases wages and the wages gap by skill. Education acts as a protection mechanism against new automation technologies.

title: Where Does Malta's P2P Rental Market Fit? A Case Study for 2023
affiliations: Central Bank of Malta

detail.title: Where Does Malta's P2P Rental Market Fit? A Case Study for 2023

publicationDetails.detailsText: Central Bank of Malta Working Paper 4/2025
publicationDetails.journalName: Central Bank of Malta Research Paper Series

publicationDetails.detailsText: Central Bank of Malta Working Paper 4/2025

detail.abstract: This study examines Malta’s peer-to-peer (P2P) rental market by comparing rental listings from Facebook Marketplace and an aggregation of real estate agencies’ adverts, while the Housing Authority’s official register is used as the benchmark characterising the local rental market. Using a combination of hedonic regression models and natural language processing techniques, including Word2Vec, Doc2Vec, and K-Means clustering, the analysis identifies key differences in pricing strategies, property characteristics, and the role of digital platforms in rental advertising. Findings reveal that advertised listings are skewed towards higher-end properties, with a greater prevalence of larger units and higher rental prices compared to the official register. Additionally, real estate agencies exhibit distinct pricing behaviours across platforms, with agency-listed properties on Facebook Marketplace generally featuring advertised rents that are between 1.5% and 2.9% lower than those posted by individual landlords. Moreover, P2P platforms usually contain a broader range of property types compared to those in aggregated agency listings. This suggests that agencies tend to use Facebook Marketplace to reach a wider audience, including lower-budget renters, while agency listings primarily cater to higher-end properties and a wealthier clientele, reflected in its higher average rental prices and greater concentration of premium listings. Linguistic analysis of property descriptions shows that comprehensive, high-quality phrasing increases rental asking prices by 3.7% to 10.2%, while the presence of specific quality-indicative words raises rents by 1.2% to 3.5%, with the range largely depending on the online platform on which an advert is posted. These findings underscore the importance of considering data source biases in rental market analysis and highlight the role of social media and platforms for real estate agencies’ listings in shaping rental market dynamics and price-setting behaviours.

title: Effectiveness of Online Education During the COVID-19 Pandemic-Evidence from Chinese Universities
affiliations: Laval University, University of Notre Dame, Virginia Tech and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Effectiveness of Online Education During the COVID-19 Pandemic-Evidence from Chinese Universities
detail.abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic triggered a global shift from face-to-face instruction to online learning, posing new operational challenges for business schools, particularly in equipping students with quantitative skills essential for the labor market. Leveraging China's abrupt lockdown policies as a natural experiment, we examine the heterogeneous effects of online education on student academic performance. Using a panel dataset of 15,329 observations from 7,867 undergraduate students across nine Chinese universities over four semesters (Fall 2018 to Spring 2020), we compare academic outcomes before and during the transition to online learning. We find that online education led to an average increase of 8 to 11 points in mathematics scores on a 100-point scale during the pandemic. Applying principal component analysis, we identify four key policy measures that capture lockdown stringency: stay-at-home orders, workplace closures, public transportation suspension, and public information campaigns. Stricter stay-at-home orders issued by the government reduce the effectiveness of online learning; however, these negative effects are partially offset by increased parental supervision and reduced external distractions resulting from workplace closures and the suspension of public transportation. Further, online learning is more effective for reasoning-focused courses (e.g., mathematics) than interpretation-focused courses (e.g., English), and the academic benefits of face-to-face peer interactions diminish significantly in online settings relative to offline environments. Our findings offer actionable insights for managing educational delivery during operational disruptions, highlighting the importance of tailoring online curriculum design and support systems to course content and student mobility constraints.

title: Misleading Advertising as a Matter of Unfair Competition Law
affiliations: Harvard Law School

detail.title: Misleading Advertising as a Matter of Unfair Competition Law

publicationDetails.detailsText: Graeme B Dinwoodie and Ansgar Ohly (eds), Research Handbook on Unfair Competition and Passing Off (Edward Elgar, forthcoming 2026)

detail.abstract: The prohibition of false and misleading advertising should be the prototypical example of unfair competition law. False and misleading advertising, after all, is generally held to be unequivocally bad, even if punishing every instance would be more costly than it’s worth. But most of modern unfair competition law, at least in the United States, is focused on different things—more in the realm of trademark law (and sometimes antitrust), and I think to its detriment. As trademark’s scope has ballooned, and as the law has tolerated more and more monopoly power, it has also tolerated more and more false advertising. A rebalancing towards false advertising could strengthen the field of unfair competition as a whole.

title: Banking for Boomers—A Field Experiment on Technology Adoption in Financial Services
affiliations: Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz - Gutenberg School of Management and Economics, Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz - Gutenberg School of Management and Economics and Catholic University of Eichstaett-Ingolstadt - Ingolstadt School of Management

detail.title: Banking for Boomers—A Field Experiment on Technology Adoption in Financial Services
detail.abstract: Digitalization in banking is leaving elderly clients at risk of losing access to financial services, but little is known about technology adoption at an advanced age. We develop and evaluate training interventions to foster internet banking adoption in a field experiment with more than 25,000 elderly clients of a large German savings bank, of whom we randomize 333 into training. Our administrative banking panel data allows us to account for selection on observables and assess the sustainability of treatment effects. After the interventions, the share of clients who use internet banking increases by 26 percentage points in the treatment group relative to a matched control group. In terms of sustainable usage, the share of online transactions increases by 13 percentage points and remains elevated four months later. An extensive placebo analysis suggests that as much as 85% of the effect can be causally attributed to the training interventions. We find that training boosts non-technical adoption skills and reduces key adoption barriers. Treatment effects are larger for women and those not in charge of household finances. We further estimate intent-to-treat effects and predict dropout along the entire multi-stage adoption process to shed light on practical considerations when rolling out large-scale technology adoption interventions in this age group. Specifically, we show that the type of training (self-guided versus social learning) impacts dropout differentially despite similar treatment effects overall, with the social learning treatment being more inclusive.

title: Digital Resilience: Navigating Change and Innovation in the Age of Chaos Through Visionary Leadership
affiliations: City University of New York (CUNY) - Koppelman School of Business and Brooklyn College Department of Business Management

detail.title: Digital Resilience: Navigating Change and Innovation in the Age of Chaos Through Visionary Leadership
detail.abstract: The digital age, marked by explosive information growth and disruptive tech, has plunged business into an "Age of Chaos." This paper examines the essential leadership qualities required to succeed in this turbulent environment. Traditional leadership, as exemplified by the decline of Kodak, Sears, and Blockbuster, struggles to adapt to rapid technological shifts and market changes. We identify nine essential leadership competencies for the digital age: fostering agility, championing an ethical culture, pursuing purpose-driven goals, maintaining technological competency, genuinely understanding diversity, demonstrating humility, exhibiting empathy, cultivating active listening, and creating cultures of appreciation and recognition. These qualities empower leaders to transform rigid organizations into adaptable powerhouses ready for anything. The paper argues that "visionary myopia"-a leader's failure to see threats and opportunities outside their traditional industry-is especially crucial.

title: An Economics of Creative Machines: The Role and Responsibility of Human-AI Creators
affiliations: Globiz Professional University

detail.title: An Economics of Creative Machines: The Role and Responsibility of Human-AI Creators
detail.abstract: This study formulates an economic framework to understand the human-AI collaboration in creative production. Building on the four-stage creativity model, creative output is modeled as a combination of human and AI knowledge through a Cobb-Douglas production function. The framework formalizes the role of AI as an integral part of creative processes, reflecting the natural tendency to incorporate new technologies into human activities. By introducing a cost minimization perspective, the model captures the transition of AI's role from generator to tool as complexity increases. Knowledge integration is quantified using Rényi entropy to assess diversity and structure. Experimental findings suggest that while AI extends the capacity to generate output, human involvement remains important in the critic process, particularly in evaluating creativity and innovation. This supports the view that AI complements, rather than replaces, human judgment in creative work.

title: ADR-Driven Development of a Multi-Agent Workspace for Productivity and Coordination
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, National University of Singapore (NUS) and National University of Singapore (NUS)

detail.title: ADR-Driven Development of a Multi-Agent Workspace for Productivity and Coordination
detail.abstract: This paper presents an Action Design Research (ADR) study on the Agentic Office System (AOS)-a multi-agent, LLM-integrated workspace designed to address fragmentation and coordination challenges in modern knowledge work. AOS unifies specialized AI agents through a shared memory layer, natural language interface, and structured collaboration mechanisms, guided by six user Requirements (R1-R6) and seven Design Principles (DP1-DP7). A low-fidelity prototype (LFP) centered on the Consensus Canvas was evaluated through a mixed-method intervention involving 12 professionals from product, design, engineering, and marketing roles. Findings showed that AOS reduced context switching, improved task efficiency, and enhanced explainability and human oversight. Guided by ADR principles such as reciprocal shaping and guided emergence, user feedback and team reflections identified improvement areas in memory continuity, model orchestration, and synchronous collaboration. These insights informed the next design iteration and yielded transferable design knowledge. AOS contributes both a working prototype and practical insights into how multi-agent, AI-augmented systems can enhance productivity and collaboration by supporting adaptive, transparent, and user-aligned workflows in enterprise environments.

title: Eroding and Non-Scalable CNN Signals: A Replication and Extension
affiliations: Poznan University of Economics and Business and University of Missouri, Columbia

detail.title: Eroding and Non-Scalable CNN Signals: A Replication and Extension
detail.abstract: We replicate Jiang et al. (2023), who report extraordinary CNN-based trading Sharpe ratios, and extend their analysis through 2023. While confirming their early results, we document a 70% decline in Sharpe ratios (10.97 to 3.34, 2001-2023) that renders the strategy economically irrelevant after transaction costs. Critically, systematic retraining on rolling windows reveals that newer data worsens performance, proving signal deterioration rather than recoverable structural change. Models trained on 2008-2015 data underperform the original 1993-2000 benchmark by 39%, contradicting conventional ML wisdom. This pre-publication decay challenges existing anomaly literature and demonstrates that CNN-based technical analysis has lost scalable economic relevance.

title: Wearing Sustainability in the Metaverse: How Platform Features and Values Shape Green Fashion Choices
affiliations: Yonsei University and Hansung University

detail.title: Wearing Sustainability in the Metaverse: How Platform Features and Values Shape Green Fashion Choices
detail.abstract: This study investigates how the characteristics of metaverse platforms and various consumption values influence consumer attitudes and purchase intentions toward metaverse sustainable fashion products. It further explores whether these relationships differ according to consumers’ levels of environmental awareness. The two key platform characteristics examined were presence and interactivity, both of which were found to positively influence consumer attitudes and purchase intentions. In terms of consumption value, epistemic, conditional, and social values showed significant positive effects on both attitude and purchase intention. Functional value exhibited no significant impact, while emotional value influenced only purchase intention but not attitude. Additionally, a positive relationship was confirmed between consumer attitude and purchase intention toward metaverse sustainable fashion products. The study also reveals that consumers with high environmental awareness scored higher in all variables related to platform characteristics, except for presence, compared to those with lower awareness. These findings provide meaningful implications for marketers and platform developers by highlighting the need to align immersive platform features and value-driven communication strategies with varying levels of consumer environmental consciousness.

title: Is Robotics Marketing the Future Concept of the Modern Marketing? A Study from a Developing Nation Perspective
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Is Robotics Marketing the Future Concept of the Modern Marketing? A Study from a Developing Nation Perspective
detail.abstract: This study investigates the adoption and consumer acceptance of robotics marketing in Bangladesh, a developing nation at the threshold of digitalization. By integrating Anthropomorphism Theory and the Technology Acceptance Model, this study provides a comprehensive framework to examine how anthropomorphic traits, subcultural appeal, resistance to change, and robot quality influence utilitarian attitudes and technological interaction resulting to user satisfaction and service robot use intention, with familiarity of appearance as a potential moderator. This quantitative study was conducted on 404 respondents from a robotics marketing foundation using a structured questionnaire and examined through Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM). The findings indicate that anthropomorphism and subcultural appeal significantly influence increasing utilitarian attitudes, while modification resistance and robot quality influence technological interaction. Utilitarian attitude and technological interaction both positively influence satisfaction and usage intention. Moreover, familiarity with appearance moderates several of these relationships. This study provides theory and conceptual contributions by combining affective and cognitive factors within technology adoption frameworks, especially in low-technology environments.

title: A Primer on the Different Meanings of "Bias" for Legal Practice
affiliations: Covington & Burling LLP and University of Waterloo - David R. Cheriton School of Computer Science

detail.title: A Primer on the Different Meanings of "Bias" for Legal Practice

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Author Tara S. Emory and Author Maura R. Grossman have no known conflicts of interest.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This work does not involve a study with patients or participants; no ethics approval is required.
declarations.funderStatement: Author Tara S. Emory's work is funded by the law firm of Covington & Burling LLP; Author Maura R. Grossman's work is funded by NSERC Discovery and NSERC CREATE grants.

contentType.other: Preprint of a paper that has already been accepted for publication

detail.abstract: As artificial intelligence ("AI") becomes increasingly integrated into the legal system, judges and attorneys must grapple with the term “bias,” which has multiple, context-specific meanings. This article offers a practical taxonomy of the different uses of the term “bias” in AI systems to support more precise legal, ethical, and technical analysis. It distinguishes between productive tendencies that enable functionality, statistical or mathematical deviations that may reduce accuracy, technical uses of the term in model design, and discriminatory outcomes that implicate civil rights law. Through examples drawn from both technical and legal practice, the article demonstrates how these meanings overlap and diverge, and how lawyers and judges can identify and mitigate harmful forms of bias without undermining the utility of AI tools. The framework supports more informed communication between legal and technical professionals and equips legal actors to assess bias in procurement, governance, and litigation involving AI systems.

title: The Information Effect of XBRL Extensions: The Role of Accruals and Note Disclosures
affiliations: University of Bremen - Faculty of Business Studies and Economics - Chair of Accounting and Control and University of Bremen

detail.title: The Information Effect of XBRL Extensions: The Role of Accruals and Note Disclosures
detail.abstract: This study examines how XBRL extensions in financial reports affect information asymmetry, distinguishing between accrual accounting elements (financial statements) and note disclosures. We show that the implications of XBRL extensions depend on whether they are applied to the highly standardized financial statements or lowly standardized note disclosures. We find that information asymmetry is increased by extensions in financial statements and decreased by extensions in note disclosures. This is consistent with XBRL extensions reducing comparability in financial statements, while at the same time providing useful firm-specific details in note disclosures. Our results support filers in better aligning their use of XBRL extensions with their reporting intentions and encourage regulators to limit extensive tagging in the accrual accounting elements of financial reports.

title: What Does Google Generative AI Think About Its Own Agency, Accountability and Parallel to Mary Shelley's Frankenstein?
affiliations: Prairie View A&M University - College of Business

detail.title: What Does Google Generative AI Think About Its Own Agency, Accountability and Parallel to Mary Shelley's Frankenstein?
detail.abstract: "My chat with ChatGPT regarding Black laborers' influence on Frederick W. Taylor's Principles of Scientific management, May 3, 2024" proved interesting as ChatGPT seemed to placate to my inquisition. AI omitted Taylor's family history as participants in the underground railroad, a family of abolitionists (Bell, 2024). An omission error occurs when relevant facts are omitted which could completely alter the nature of a conclusion drawn from information in the premises. It is difficult to imply a 19 th Century person is likely racist when that same person comes from a family of abolitionists actively willing to die to end slavery. AI at times did appear, in that May 3, 2024 conversation, to actively ingratiate itself to my line of inquiry as its inquisitor; ingratiation is a commonly known impression management strategy used in interpersonal communication by a subordinate to garner an advantage or benefit from a superior. In our book, Managerial Communication for Professional Development, Bell and Martin (2019) cover Impression Management in Chapter 2, where we explain ingratiation as "flattery" and "favor-doing" as an assertive strategy. AI appeared in that conversation to be programmed to used ingratiation as an assertive strategy. On June 28, 2025, I had a chat with Google Generative AI on what it thought about its own agency, accountability and parallel to Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.

title: Social Interaction and Feedback-Giving Behavior in the Sharing Economy - An Experimental Analysis
affiliations: Paderborn University and Paderborn University

detail.title: Social Interaction and Feedback-Giving Behavior in the Sharing Economy - An Experimental Analysis
detail.abstract: Sharing economy platforms such as Airbnb or Uber have experienced substantial growth in both transaction volume and revenue generation. Due to the intimate nature of the arrangements offered (home stay, car share), these markets critically depend on trust. However, reputation systems, which should promote trust in online markets, frequently generate overly positive ratings-a phenomenon empirical studies have shown to be particularly pronounced on sharing economy platforms. The positively skewed distributions put accuracy into question and consequently undermine the credibility of feedback. As social interactions are a key characteristic of sharing economy transactions, we examine whether the exchange of personal information between transaction partners influences customer feedback and whether this effect is conditional on interpersonal liking. Since the frequency and intensity of these social interactions cannot be directly observed in field settings, we designed a laboratory experiment that simulates a sharing economy market. This setting allows us to vary the availability of personal information and thus to directly compare the feedback behavior of participants who have access to that personal information with those who do not. Our results confirm the existence of a social premium: customers rate providers significantly higher when provided with personal information, regardless of whether their performance expectations are met. Furthermore, we find that interpersonal liking positively influences rating scores, revealing a mechanism through which social information affects feedback provision. We offer specific proposals that account for these social information effects, and which, by generating more dispersed and differentiated feedback, would benefit platform providers and market participants alike.

title: Potential of Quantum Data Management to Improve the Environmental Impact of IT
affiliations: University of Virginia

detail.title: Potential of Quantum Data Management to Improve the Environmental Impact of IT
detail.abstract: The ever-increasing global demand for computational power has led to escalating energy consumption within the IT sector. Traditional data management approaches, reliant on classical computing infrastructures, struggle to keep pace with both the data explosion and the need for energy efficiency. Quantum computing, with its fundamentally different processing capabilities, offers a promising alternative. This paper explores the potential of quantum data management to significantly reduce IT energy consumption, emphasizing the mechanisms through which quantum technologies can optimize storage, retrieval, and processing while minimizing resource usage.

title: Introducing a Multi-Agent System Approach to Psychological Safety in Diverse Teams: An Organizational Behavior Perspective
affiliations: Stevens Institute of Technology

detail.title: Introducing a Multi-Agent System Approach to Psychological Safety in Diverse Teams: An Organizational Behavior Perspective
detail.abstract: In modern organizational behavior and design research, implying machine learning techniques have become the major computational approach, machine learning can excel tasks with labeled data. However, they cannot explain why these patterns emerge, are not equipped to test unknown interventions, and are incapable of exploring causal mechanisms underlying organizational phenomena. In this study, we introduce a multi-agent system approach to simulate 2160 teams and we identify psychological safety is the main factor of diversity's impact. The team's performance reached a peak when diversity ranges from 0.68-0.72, it delivered a massive 34% gain-under the condition that psychological safety surpasses 0.53. Reversing its effect from negative (r =-0.34) to positive (r = 0.52). The performance improved 38% despite the conflict having decreased 64%. Especially the early-stage behavioral shaping is 3.8 times more effective than delayed interventions. Behavioral patterns: Empathic mirroring amplifies psychological safety (+0.23), while exclusion mitigates it (-0.31). Multi-agent system discloses the fundamental structure-psychological safety lessens diversity's organization costs via refined communication channels. The model's validation (r = 0.71) confirms the robust predictive power, and optimized teams operate 47% better-these insights have not been discovered by machine learning frameworks.

title: Artificial Intelligence as a Platform Technology: Strategic Implications of Competing on Top of an AI Platform
affiliations: Northeastern University, Copenhagen Business School - Department of Strategy and Innovation and University of Southern California, Marshall School of Business

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence as a Platform Technology: Strategic Implications of Competing on Top of an AI Platform
detail.abstract: Artificial Intelligence is a transformative technology, but there exists considerable uncertainty about its evolution and impact on firms, society, and the economy. The development of Generative Artificial Intelligence and Large Language Models in many ways parallels the structure of other technology platforms and ecosystems. In this chapter, we discuss the development of Artificial Intelligence technologies (particularly Generative Transformer-Based Artificial Intelligence such as Large Language Models) and explore the similarities to platform ecosystems. We then discuss how learnings from research in platforms can apply to Artificial Intelligence and implications for competitive strategies of firms, innovation by firms, and broader implications of these technologies diffusing across the economy.

title: Enhancing Data Privacy in Federated Learning: A Cryptographic Perspective
affiliations: Wilfrid Laurier University and Wilfrid Laurier University

detail.title: Enhancing Data Privacy in Federated Learning: A Cryptographic Perspective
detail.abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training without sharing raw data, but remains vulnerable to inference attacks and untrusted aggregators. To address these risks, recent studies integrate cryptographic techniques such as homomorphic encryption (HE), secure aggregation, and post-quantum cryptography (PQC) into the FL pipeline. This systematic literature review (SLR) synthesizes 45 peer-reviewed studies published between 2022 and 2025. Following a PRISMAcompliant process, we classified cryptographic techniques, analyzed their reported privacy guarantees, computational and communication overheads, and identified practical implementation challenges. HE is the most common approach (51.6%), while hybrid and PQC-based schemes remain underexplored. Reporting quality varies widely across threat modeling, reproducibility, and scalability metrics. Our findings highlight a shift from cryptographic proofs of concept to system-level trade-off evaluations. The review identifies critical gaps in standardized evaluation, threat modeling, and resource-aware deployment, offering actionable guidance for future research in privacypreserving FL.

title: The Amplification and Perpetuation of AI-Derived Biases Through Automation Dependency: A Framework for Understanding the Long-Term Cognitive and Social Implications of LLM Over-Reliance
affiliations: King’s College London, Dickson Poon School of Law

detail.title: The Amplification and Perpetuation of AI-Derived Biases Through Automation Dependency: A Framework for Understanding the Long-Term Cognitive and Social Implications of LLM Over-Reliance
detail.abstract: This research introduces a framework to elucidate how automation bias in Large Language Models (LLMs) amplifies biases through human over-reliance, leading to critical thinking atrophy and the propagation of biases into human cognition and social systems. Automation bias, defined as the tendency to excessively trust AI outputs while ignoring contradictory evidence or personal judgment, drives a three-phase cycle: (1) initial dependency development, fueled by perceived AI efficiency; (2) critical thinking atrophy via cognitive offloading; and (3) bias internalization and propagation, where AI biases are inherited and reproduced in human decisions, even without AI support (Kosmyna et al., 2025). Drawing on evidence such as the impact of AI on 40% of global jobs (Georgieva, 2024) and cognitive offloading in education (Kosmyna et al., 2025), we challenge the notion that technical fixes alone can mitigate these effects. We propose Wisdom as a Service (WaaS), a preliminary framework that integrates non-European wisdom traditions… This theoretical approach prioritizes epistemic pluralism and community validation as potential pathways to address the long-term societal consequences of AI over-reliance (inspired by Cleverly (2025), integrating non-European wisdom traditions (e.g., Ubuntu, Nyāya) and decolonized AI architectures to disrupt bias amplification). Automation bias is not just a human-AI interaction problem but a sociocognitive epidemic. Without systemic intervention (e.g., WaaS, decolonized AI), AI biases will become permanent fixtures of human reasoning. This framework prioritizes epistemic multiplicity, community validation, and culturally grounded reasoning to address the long-term societal consequences of AI over-reliance.

title: Draea: Directed Relation-Aware Representation Learning for Entity Alignment
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Draea: Directed Relation-Aware Representation Learning for Entity Alignment
detail.abstract: Entity Alignment (EA) is a crucial technique for Knowledge Graph (KG) integration, aiming to identify equivalent entities across different KGs based on a set of pre-aligned seed pairs. However, existing methods for relation modeling often overly rely on the local structural features of entities, neglecting the inherent characteristics of relationships. Moreover, the directionality of relations is frequently overlooked, thereby limiting the expressive power of models in capturing complex relational directions. To address these challenges, we propose a novel entity alignment framework named Directed Relation-Aware Representation Learning for Entity Alignment (DRAEA). Specifically, as a dual-module learning framework, DRAEA enables simultaneous and decoupled modeling of the entity structure and directed relational features. Furthermore, a direction-enhanced relation representation module is designed that constructs a line graph based on the directed relations in KG. This enables the model to learn the directional relational features explicitly. DRAEA achieves an end-to-end fusion of structural learning and relation modeling in a novel and effective method. Extensive experiments on public benchmarks show that our model achieves state-of-the-art performance, surpassing the best baseline by up to 1.69% in H@1 on DBP15K.

title: Understanding Ai's Role in Society and Workplace Through Technology, Trust, and Anticipatory Emotion Factors
affiliations: University of Connecticut and University of Connecticut

detail.title: Understanding Ai's Role in Society and Workplace Through Technology, Trust, and Anticipatory Emotion Factors
detail.abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) plays a role in many facets of our society, ranging from information assistance, educational learning, and customer service to health monitoring, traffic management, and task automation. As such, whether AI will impact workforce displacement in different economic sectors in the foreseeable future has also become a quintessential question in our progression toward the emerging AI age. To date, theory-driven empirical research has yet to examine the psychological factors that may affect how Gen Z, the first generation to grow up in the AI age, responds to the uncertainty associated with the future of work. Drawing from the literature on Computers as Social Actors (CASA) paradigm, technology fluidity theory, sociotechnical blindness theory, and emotion and adaptation theory, this study tests how AI-use fluidity and familiarity may influence Gen Z’s acceptance of and trust in AI as well as their cognitive and affective reactions toward AI’s role in the future workplace. Results showed that as AI-human interaction fluidity was positively related to AI-use knowledge and humanoid robot acceptance, while mistrust and fear positively predicted perceived future AI displacement of human workforce. The findings also indicated that individuals with higher humanoid-AI acceptance showed greater AI trust as well as more hopeful feelings and less fearful feelings toward AI. Lastly, fearful feelings also outpaced hopeful feelings, as anticipated.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Rainfall-Runoff Forecasting Model Incorporating Spatiotemporal Information from Multi-Source Data
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan University, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology and Huazhong University of Science and Technology

detail.title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Rainfall-Runoff Forecasting Model Incorporating Spatiotemporal Information from Multi-Source Data
detail.abstract: Deep learning has been widely applied in runoff forecasting, focusing primarily on temporal features but neglecting the influence of spatial heterogeneity. Capturing the complex spatiotemporal atmosphere–land–hydrology interactions using deep learning remains challenging for accurate rainfall–runoff forecasting. This study proposes a hybrid deep learning framework, Runoff Forecasting Model Integrating Spatiotemporal Features (RFMISF), which leverages the complementary strengths of multiple deep learning architectures to construct five modules, thereby fusing multi-source data. Specifically, the framework integrates Convolutional Neural Networks for extracting spatial features of underlying surface, LSTM for capturing temporal dependencies in rainfall and runoff, and Convolutional LSTM (ConvLSTM) for learning spatiotemporal features of meteorological inputs. The proposed model was applied to daily runoff forecasting at BHT and SBY hydrological stations with distinct hydrological regimes. At BHT, RFMISF reduced RMSE by 13.7% and MAE by 24.7% compared to the LSTM baseline. At SBY, it improved NSE by 13.63% and decreased MAE by 16.19%. Ablation experiments further demonstrated the importance of multi-source data. The exclusion of station rainfall, underlying surface, and meteorological data led to RMSE increases of 9.29%, 4.69%, and 5.59% at BHT during flood season, respectively. At SBY, the corresponding reductions in NSE were 15.08%, 4.46%, and 12.94%. Additionally, model performance varies with rainfall intensity, indicating the differentiated contributions of multi-source data in complex runoff responses. Although reanalysis data enhance spatial representativeness, their systematic errors require careful treatment. Overall, this study introduces a novel, robust framework for enhancing runoff prediction and improving water resource management in hydrologically complex environments.

title: When Disclosure Pays: Evidence from the Over-The-Counter Markets
affiliations: Stanford Law School and Stanford Law School

detail.title: When Disclosure Pays: Evidence from the Over-The-Counter Markets
detail.abstract: This paper examines the impact of the 2021 amendments to SEC Rule 15c2-11, which imposed new public disclosure requirements on OTC-traded firms that wished to retain a publicly accessible quotation. Using an event study framework, we analyze how firms’ decisions to disclose—or not—affected market liquidity and valuation. We find that firms that complied with the rule experienced immediate improvements in liquidity and significant positive market-adjusted returns, whereas firms that failed to disclose experienced a sharp drop in liquidity as they were relegated to a restricted “Expert Market” platform. Notably, firms benefited even when disclosing seemingly lackluster financial information. For example, the set of newly compliant firms that disclosed a greater financial loss than reported in their most recent prior disclosure experienced a mean three-day cumulative market-adjusted return of 19.5%.

title: Financial Incentives, Public Finance, and Performance of Medical Consortia
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Xi'an Jiaotong University (XJTU)

detail.title: Financial Incentives, Public Finance, and Performance of Medical Consortia
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of financial incentives on the performance of medical consortia (MCs) in the context of integrated healthcare reform in China. Using panel data from a sample of province-level medical consortia and applying fixed effects regression models, we find robust evidence that financial incentives significantly enhance MC performance. Furthermore, we explore the moderating role of public fiscal support and demonstrate that the effect of financial incentives is stronger in regions with higher levels of fiscal capacity. Subsample analysis reveals that the performance-enhancing impact of FI is notably more prominent in economically developed regions and in areas with richer medical resource endowment. The study contributes to the literature by offering novel empirical insights into how performance-based reforms operate in developing country settings, and highlights the importance of aligning incentive structures with local fiscal and institutional conditions.

title: Human Rights Implications of Digital Trade Law
affiliations: University of Lucerne

detail.title: Human Rights Implications of Digital Trade Law
detail.abstract: Digital trade law has become one of the most dynamic fields of international law, as individual states and the global community have engaged in creating a new, albeit fragmented, rule-framework for the data-driven economy. This has unfolded almost exclusively through bilateral and regional trade agreements that regulate the digital economy by devising specific and at times far-reaching rules on non-discrimination of digital products, source code and cross-border data flows, to name but a few. Many of these economically driven provisions and the changes that they trigger in domestic regulatory regimes have serious human rights implications. Some of the tensions, in particular around personal data protection, have found reflection in policy and academic discussions. The implications for other human rights have been however often ignored. It is the article’s objective to address this gap. First, by providing a detailed analysis of the current digital trade law framework, advanced through far-reaching treaties, such as the CPTPP and the USMCA and the new generation of Digital Economy Agreements (DEAs). Second, by exploring the human rights implications of selected provisions in more detail, starting with the more conventional discussion of privacy and then freedom of speech, and moving towards the less explored interfaces with development. The article’s overall enquiry seeks to feed into a more nuanced discussion of digital trade regulation and towards better interfacing of digital trade law with human rights.

detail.abstract: We examine the strategic considerations and effects of product placement services in digital content aggregators, focusing in particular on Spotify's "Discovery Mode". Discovery Mode introduces bias in users' consumption bundle that content providers pay through discounted royalties, and triggers users to actively adjust to it in response. The platform's ability to manipulate consumption bundles (and adjust users' participation fee consistently) leads to promotion of the cheapest content available and degradation of users' effective consumption bundles. In equilibrium, Discovery Mode can either benefit or harm the provider of the cheapest content to stream, with the harm arising whenever Discovery Mode threatens to revert preexisting bias against said provider. Importantly, Discovery Mode always forces users to costly adjust their consumption more, unequivocally generating loss of efficiency in the market. We further highlight an indirect increase in the risk of market concentration stemming from the platform's ability to bias consumption.

title: Optimal R&D Investment and Economic Growth: A Global Test of the Armey Curve
affiliations: KISTEP Korea Institute of S&T Evalution and Planning and Georgia Institute of Technology

detail.title: Optimal R&D Investment and Economic Growth: A Global Test of the Armey Curve
detail.abstract: Research and development (R&D) investment is a primary driver of productivity enhancement and economic growth. Despite numerous discussions on the relationship between R&D investment and economic growth or productivity, some limitations remain, such as the predominant focus on OECD countries and methodological neglect of cross-sectional dependence. In this study, we examine the optimal ratio of R&D investment for economic growth, using panel time-series data spanning 33 years (1985-2017) for 72 countries, including both OECD member and non-member countries. The analysis reveals an inverted U-shaped relationship, known as the Armey Curve between R&D investment and economic growth, similar to the relationship often observed in public finance. Also, the optimal ratio of R&D investment for economic growth varies depending on country-specific heterogeneity, the consideration of unobserved common factors, and strong cross-sectional dependence. These findings highlight the need for context-sensitive R&D allocation strategies and point to further research avenues.

title: Strategies for Units Incentivization: Assessing Influence by Maximizing Loss/Gain in Centrally Managed Systems
affiliations: University of Western Ontario - Ivey Business School, Ivey Business School, University of Western Ontario and McGill University

detail.title: Strategies for Units Incentivization: Assessing Influence by Maximizing Loss/Gain in Centrally Managed Systems
detail.abstract: In the context of centrally managed systems (CMSs), accurately determining the influence of units is crucial for effective incentive and compensation plans. Previous attempts to measure the impact of a specific DMU involved evaluating overall system efficiency after removing that DMU. However, challenges arise in accurately assessing post-removal system efficiency primarily because the aggregate unit fails to represent the transformed system adequately. The lack of modification to the remaining DMUs results in a disparity between the average of the remaining DMUs and the previous aggregate unit. Consequently, calculating the overall efficiency of the new system using the previous aggregate unit becomes imprecise and lacks meaningful insight. We develop a new incentivization method involving the redistribution of the DMU under evaluation among the remaining units to maintain the representativeness of the aggregate DMU before and after the removal of the DMU under evaluation. We propose two models to calculate the maximum loss and gain for each inefficient and efficient DMU during this redistribution, respectively. Our method also demonstrates robustness when assessing the contributions of efficient DMUs in the presence of nearby masked units. We provide adaptations for inefficient DMUs near efficient ones but significantly distant from other groups of inefficient units, ensuring precise scoring. Our approach is demonstrated using a real dataset.

title: The Effect of Learning Concentration on Improving the Quality of Student Human Resources in the Digital Era
affiliations: Universitas Muhammadiyah Palopo

detail.title: The Effect of Learning Concentration on Improving the Quality of Student Human Resources in the Digital Era
detail.abstract: The digital era has brought great transformations in the world of higher education, especially in the way students learn, access information, and build intellectual capacity. This change requires students to have a high concentration of learning as the main foundation in forming superior and competitive quality of human resources (HR). Concentration in learning, as the ability to focus full attention on the learning process, is now a challenge due to the increase in digital distractions such as social media, app notifications, and a multitasking lifestyle. This study aims to analyze the influence of learning concentration on improving the quality of student human resources in the digital era, focusing on cognitive, emotional, and professional aspects. The research method used is a quantitative approach with a simple linear regression analysis technique to determine the relationship between variables. The results of the study show that learning concentration has a significant influence on the quality of student human resources, shown through improving critical thinking skills, good time management, academic discipline, and readiness to face the world of work. This study concludes that learning concentration is not only an important element in academic success, but also contributes to the formation of students' character, integrity, and competence holistically. Therefore, universities need to design learning strategies and academic support that can strengthen students' concentration skills in order to produce a generation of human resources who are ready to compete in the digital era.

title: The Taxation of Corporate Digital Entities under the MLC: A Critique of the Rule of Permanent Establishment
affiliations: University of Florida

detail.title: The Taxation of Corporate Digital Entities under the MLC: A Critique of the Rule of Permanent Establishment
detail.abstract: The digital economy has significantly enhanced efficiency and fostered innovation, thus leading to improved accessibility of goods and services. It also promotes sustainable development and economic growth. However, this digital transformation is accompanied by complex policy challenges, particularly in regard to the taxation of corporate entities. It is evident that establishing a stable and well-organized international tax framework is essential to address the issues associated with taxing this digital economy and to earn the trust of all stakeholders involved. In response to these issues, the global tax community has initiated collective efforts to create a robust tax framework. This effort is reflected in the agreement reached by 138 countries on a two-pillar approach. Pillar One concentrates on establishing rules for nexus and profit allocation, while Pillar Two introduces a global minimum tax designed to mitigate the unresolved issues related to Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS). This approach is anticipated to foster equity and fairness in taxation and also empower international economies to adapt to evolving business models and profit realization tactics employed by multinational enterprises. Many of these entities have resorted to aggressive tax strategies and profit-shifting techniques in order to navigate the challenging financial eceonomy exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. This paper aims to explore and evaluate the effectiveness of the taxation frameworks for digital entities as outlined in the OECD Model Tax Convention. It also examines the design of the Multilateral Convention to Implement Tax Treaty Related Measures to Prevent Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (MLC). Through this analysis, the paper provides insights and recommendations for enhancing tax frameworks and addressing the unique challenges posed by the digital economy.

title: Domestic Illicit Financial Flows in Africa: Theories, Mechanisms, and Case Studies
affiliations: DERISKING ADVISORY / Global Association of Certified Anti-illicit Financial Flows (GACAIFFP)/ African Society for Corporate Compliance et Ethics (ASCCE)

detail.title: Domestic Illicit Financial Flows in Africa: Theories, Mechanisms, and Case Studies
detail.abstract: Illicit financial flows (IFFs) within national boundaries, or domestic IFFs, represent a significant but understudied challenge in Africa, where they undermine economic development, erode public trust, and exacerbate inequality. Unlike cross-border IFFs, which are estimated at $50–100 billion annually, domestic IFFs lack precise quantification, with rough estimates suggesting $17.7–$35.4 billion annually. This paper develops six theoretical frameworks to explain domestic IFFs: Opaque Ownership, Proxy Facilitation, Institutional Exploitation, Jurisdictional Arbitrage, Professional Intermediary Networks, and Government Contract Exploitation. These theories focus on mechanisms such as straw individuals, fake or anonymous companies, and insider collusion, supported by African case studies like Kenya’s Goldenberg scandal, Nigeria’s public sector fraud, and Ghana’s banking crisis. Using a mixed-methods approach, the paper analyzes these mechanisms, their economic impact, and policy implications, aligning with frameworks like the UN Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC) and the African Union’s Agenda 2063.

title: Discrimination Preferences
affiliations: Aarhus University, Department of Economics and Business Economics and Aarhus University

detail.title: Discrimination Preferences
detail.abstract: We reconsider discrimination preferences through moral lenses and conduct experiments to systematically investigate these preferences using representative UK samples. Specifically, we evaluate the distribution of individual preferences for and against taste-and statistical-based discrimination across three domains—ethnicity, gender, and LGBTQ+ status. Using over 60,000 anonymous decisions affecting how workers are paid from more than 3,500 individuals, we document that most individuals prefer to engage in at least one type of discrimination, that there is substantial heterogeneity in preferences, and that the existence of multiple preferences changes our understanding of why individuals engage or not in discrimination. Among others, we examine how preferences relate across domains, map them onto socio-demographic characteristics, politics, support for policies, and gender wage gaps, and study underlying redistributive principles and effects of wage transparency.

title: From Debt to Divestiture: How Indian and Global Firms Reshaped through Corporate Restructuring
affiliations: ICFAI Business School (IBS) Hyderabad, India

detail.title: From Debt to Divestiture: How Indian and Global Firms Reshaped through Corporate Restructuring
detail.abstract: This study provides an analysis of major corporate restructuring events between 2010 and 2025, focusing on India alongside global benchmarks. It explores why firms restructure, highlighting triggers such as unsustainable debt, regulatory shifts, strategic refocusing, and pressures to unlock shareholder value. The study examines how firms execute these transformations through mergers, demergers, asset divestitures, debt refinancing, and organizational realignments. Covering ten prominent Indian cases (including Reliance Industries, Tata Group, Adani Group, HDFC-HDFC Bank, and JSW Steel) and five global counterparts (General Electric, Siemens, Vodafone, IBM, and Volkswagen), it assesses the restructuring processes and outcomes. Key insights reveal that high debt levels often precipitated asset sales and equity infusions, while conglomerate discounts led firms to spin off focused entities, enhancing valuations. Regulatory frameworks like India's Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) catalysed distress resolutions, as seen in steel and power sector turnarounds. Successful restructurings typically featured robust due diligence, clear communication, and meticulous post-deal integration. Conversely, weak governance and legal entanglements, exemplified by the Future Group's collapse, underscore potential pitfalls. Financially, many firms emerged leaner and more profitable. Reliance became net debt-free and diversified into digital and retail, while HDFC Bank's merger positioned it among the world's top banks by market cap. Yet, cases like Vodafone highlight that restructuring is not universally successful without sustained strategic and financial discipline. The study also underscores future research avenues, including long-term performance of spun-off entities and the growing role of ESG considerations in restructuring decisions. Recommendations are offered for corporates, finance practitioners, and policymakers to approach restructuring as a proactive strategic renewal tool, supported by rigorous financial modeling, transparent communication, and regulatory fine-tuning to protect stakeholder interests.

title: Modeling Mode Choice Preferences of E-Scooter Users Using Machine Learning Methods – Case of Istanbul

detail.title: Modeling Mode Choice Preferences of E-Scooter Users Using Machine Learning Methods – Case of Istanbul
detail.abstract: Delays resulting from motor vehicle traffic, traffic accidents, and environmental pollution pose significant challenges in contemporary society. To tackle these issues, users of transportation systems are encouraged to engage in active transportation methods and micromobility options alongside public transit. Electric scooters have emerged as a popular micromobility solution, particularly following the introduction of vehicle-sharing companies in 2018, a trend that was further accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic.This study explored the demographic characteristics, attitudes, and behaviors of e-scooter users in Istanbul through an online survey conducted between September 1, 2023, and May 1, 2024. A total of 462 e-scooter users were surveyed on their preferred transportation mode across 24 various scenarios devised for the study. The responses from participants were analyzed using Artificial Neural Networks, Decision Trees, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting methods. Among the models developed, Random Forest demonstrated the highest performance, achieving an accuracy rate of 96,51%, significantly exceeding the performance of discrete choice models reported in the literature.The models created in this study can serve multiple purposes for scientific researchers, central and local authorities, as well as shared e-scooter service providers, aiding in their strategic and operational decision-making processes. Future research can seek to employ different machine learning methodologies and develop a model that better reflects individual preferences across various cities.

title: Remaining Useful Lifetime Prediction of Turbofan Engines Based on Hybrid Transformer Deep Architecture
affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology and Université de Lille

detail.title: Remaining Useful Lifetime Prediction of Turbofan Engines Based on Hybrid Transformer Deep Architecture
detail.abstract: Remaining useful life (RUL) refers to the period during which a machine is likely to function well before requiring any repair or replacement.  Predicting the RUL accurately is critical to prognostics and health management, enabling engineers to make reasonable and practical decisions that retain the continuous operation of the machinery and reduce repair costs. This study proposes a novel hybrid deep learning-based method that combines a 1D Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and two consecutive transformer encoders for RUL prediction. The use of 1D CNN is to extract spatial features, while the transformer encoders are for capturing long-term dependencies from input sequences. A Fourier transform is integrated into the second transformer encoder to increase training speed and model lightness. In addition, a Bayesian optimization (BO) algorithm is applied to find out the optimal hyperparameters of the model. Several experiments have been conducted to investigate the effectiveness of BO and evaluate the performance of the proposed model based on two well-known turbofan engine datasets, namely the Commercial Modular Aero-Propulsion System (C-MAPSS) benchmark dataset and its new version (N-CMAPSS). The results show that the proposed model performs better on accuracy and lightness than the current state-of-the-art RUL prediction methods.

detail.abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) offers adaptive solutions to portfolio optimization, yet standard methods such as proximal policy optimization (PPO) rely exclusively on historical price data and overlook the impact of investor sentiment. We introduce sentiment-augmented PPO (SAPPO), a reinforcement learning framework that incorporates real-time sentiment signals extracted from Refinitiv financial news. Daily sentiment scores are generated using LLaMA 3.3. SAPPO integrates these signals into the PPO advantage function via a sentiment-weighted term, enabling allocation strategies that respond to both price movements and market sentiment. Experiments on a three-asset portfolio demonstrate that SAPPO increases the Sharpe ratio from 1.55 to 1.90 and reduces drawdowns relative to PPO. The optimal configuration uses a sentiment influence parameter λ = 0.1, as validated through ablation studies and statistically significant t-tests (p < 0.001). These findings show that sentiment-aware reinforcement learning improves trading performance and offers a robust alternative to purely pricebased strategies.

title: Pooling Goods of Different Quality: Platform Design under Inventory Commingling
affiliations: University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business and New York University (NYU) - NYU Tandon School of Engineering

detail.title: Pooling Goods of Different Quality: Platform Design under Inventory Commingling
detail.abstract: This paper studies inventory commingling in third-party (3P) marketplaces, a fulfillment practice where identical items from different sellers are pooled and shipped interchangeably. While commingling improves efficiency for both the platform and the sellers, it creates quality risks when sellers differ in product quality and this information is privately held. We develop a game-theoretic model of a platform that sets its fulfillment fee while sellers, differentiated by quality, decide whether to participate in commingling. We characterize the resulting equilibrium outcomes and uncover a form of market stratification: lower-quality sellers either avoid the platform entirely or join only by commingling, whereas higher-quality sellers always remain but in some cases may opt out of commingling to shield their customers from quality spillovers. We show that commingling consistently improves the profits of the platform and lower-quality sellers. However, it may hurt higher-quality sellers, even if they opt out: not through quality risk, but via the platform's endogenous increase of the fulfillment fee. Importantly, we identify market conditions where commingling improves outcomes for all parties. Our paper provides platform managers with a framework to evaluate when and how to offer inventory commingling. By pinpointing market conditions where commingling boosts profits, expands seller participation, or threatens product quality, we offer actionable guidance for aligning fulfillment design with strategic objectives.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Rainfall-Runoff Forecasting Model Incorporating Spatiotemporal Information from Multi-Source Data
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan University, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology and Huazhong University of Science and Technology

detail.title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Rainfall-Runoff Forecasting Model Incorporating Spatiotemporal Information from Multi-Source Data
detail.abstract: Deep learning has been widely applied in runoff forecasting, focusing primarily on temporal features but neglecting the influence of spatial heterogeneity. Capturing the complex spatiotemporal atmosphere–land–hydrology interactions using deep learning remains challenging for accurate rainfall–runoff forecasting. This study proposes a hybrid deep learning framework, Runoff Forecasting Model Integrating Spatiotemporal Features (RFMISF), which leverages the complementary strengths of multiple deep learning architectures to construct five modules, thereby fusing multi-source data. Specifically, the framework integrates Convolutional Neural Networks for extracting spatial features of underlying surface, LSTM for capturing temporal dependencies in rainfall and runoff, and Convolutional LSTM (ConvLSTM) for learning spatiotemporal features of meteorological inputs. The proposed model was applied to daily runoff forecasting at BHT and SBY hydrological stations with distinct hydrological regimes. At BHT, RFMISF reduced RMSE by 13.7% and MAE by 24.7% compared to the LSTM baseline. At SBY, it improved NSE by 13.63% and decreased MAE by 16.19%. Ablation experiments further demonstrated the importance of multi-source data. The exclusion of station rainfall, underlying surface, and meteorological data led to RMSE increases of 9.29%, 4.69%, and 5.59% at BHT during flood season, respectively. At SBY, the corresponding reductions in NSE were 15.08%, 4.46%, and 12.94%. Additionally, model performance varies with rainfall intensity, indicating the differentiated contributions of multi-source data in complex runoff responses. Although reanalysis data enhance spatial representativeness, their systematic errors require careful treatment. Overall, this study introduces a novel, robust framework for enhancing runoff prediction and improving water resource management in hydrologically complex environments.

title: Linking Sustainability Practices to Financial Success: Insights from Bangladesh
affiliations: Chittagong Independent University

detail.title: Linking Sustainability Practices to Financial Success: Insights from Bangladesh
detail.abstract: The rapid industrialization and economic growth of Bangladesh, particularly in the ready-made garment sector, have raised significant concerns about sustainability. This study investigates how businesses and consumers in Bangladesh are incorporating sustainability into their practices and decision-making. By exploring factors influencing the adoption of these practices, their impact on financial performance, and consumer attitudes toward sustainability, the research contributes to understanding the sustainability scenario of Bangladesh. Data from 225 businesses and 639 consumers were analyzed. Findings reveal a growing emphasis on these factors among businesses, linked to improved financial outcomes. However, challenges such as consumer price sensitivity and limited knowledge about sustainability persist. While consumer awareness of sustainability is increasing, a significant segment remains willing to pay a premium for sustainable products. The study highlights the importance of businesses embracing these practices and the need for supportive policies to foster a sustainable future.

detail.abstract: U.S. hospitals lose an estimated $20 billion annually to the direct and indirect costs of preventable nurse injuries from manual patient handling. This paper provides hospital leaders with a proven 132.8%-ROI model to justify technology adoption as a key strategy for healthcare cost reduction and nurse retention. Using a case study of a 200-bed hospital, we demonstrate payback periods of under six months. The analysis is expanded into in-depth scenarios for high-risk departments, showing how a targeted investment in patient transfer technology can mitigate financial risk and address critical workforce challenges. The findings have significant implications for national workforce retention policies and offer a data-driven path to improving the financial health of U.S. healthcare institutions.

title: Inspections, Informal Payments and Tax Payments by Firms
affiliations: Oklahoma State University

detail.title: Inspections, Informal Payments and Tax Payments by Firms
detail.abstract: This paper examines the overall effect of bribe payments and inspections on firms' payment of taxes and fees. To do this we first investigate whether inspections carried out by government officials are anti-corruption instruments as often touted by governments, or whether they are another manifestation of corruption where government officials exert their power and inconvenience firms' operations, that can be tamped down by payment of bribes. Our empirical analysis finds support for the latter. While we do uncover a strong direct effect of bribe payment on lowering the tax and fees by 27%, we find that payment of bribes also reduces the number of inspections and leads to indirect benefits of tax and fees reduction. This overlooked avenue of corruption that plays out through the inspection channel is equivalent to 6% of the direct effect. Simultaneous equations model using panel data helps uncovers the direction of causality.

detail.title: A Design of 96 Gs/S 7-Bit Dac for High-Speed Wireline Transmitter in 28-Nm Cmos
detail.abstract: This paper presents a 96 GS/s 7-bit digital-to-analog converter (DAC) for a 200 Gb/s+ wireline transmitter. The impact of mismatch of current sources is reduced by introducing a dual segmentation strategy and local dynamic element matching (DEM). An 8:1 multiplexer (MUX) with edge-enhanced 1-UI pulse generator is proposed for high-speed data serialization, simplifying the clock generation circuit. In addition, the influence of the output network on the dynamic performance of the DAC is also analyzed. The proposed DAC prototype is designed based on the 28nm CMOS process. The post simulation results show that the proposed DAC achieves spurious free dynamic range (SFDR) of 37.20-dB and signal-to-noise and distortion (SNDR) of 30.91-dB at 96 GS/s sampling rate under the Nyquist output frequency. For eight level pulse amplitude modulation (PAM-8) encoding, the 288-Gb/s eye diagram demonstrates 78-mV vertical eye opening and 0.253-UI horizontal eye width, achieving 0.52 pJ/bit energy efficiency of DAC core.

detail.abstract: Evidence from local policy restrictions often guides broader regulatory decisions, but geographic spillovers may compromise the external validity of such estimates. We examine this challenge in the context of state e-cigarette flavor restrictions, where varying state sizes create natural variation in the cost of policy evasion. Using retail scanner data from 2018-2019 and a staggered difference-in-differences design, we document how geographic constraints affect policy effectiveness. The impact of sales restrictions differs systematically with state size: for every 10-mile increase in the population's average distance from borders, cross-border sales decrease by 5.6%. However, consumers in larger states show significantly higher substitution toward menthol cigarettes, with effects ranging from approximately 2% in Washington to 7% in Montana. These findings suggest that local policy experiments may systematically overestimate the effectiveness and underestimate the unintended consequences of broader implementation. Evidence from small geographic areas, where consumers easily evade restrictions through cross-border shopping, understates the potential for harmful product substitution under comprehensive regulation.

This summary also explains how the usage of TBL can help to establish sustainable and ethical commitments to Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) initiatives and programs. TBL captures the information on how much cash flow a company brings or grows while making improvements to people's benefits and the planet's commitment. Based on the article published (techterget.com, Alexander Gillis, September 2021).

detail.title: Identification and Evaluation of Influence Factors for Human-Automation Teaming Form Perspectives of Sociotechnical Systems
detail.abstract: In a near future, intelligent industrial systems will face the rapid development of cyber-physical human systems and Industry 5.0. In a modern production and control system operators are indispensable for system resilience and safety. However, as intelligent systems and agents are increasingly being applied in work areas, the design, maintenance, and supervision of human-machine systems becomes a critical issue. Meanwhile, autonomous agency has had an impact on human psychology and behavior. The aim of this research was to identify and evaluate the factors influencing the collaborative performance of human-automation teams (HAT) from a socio-technical systems perspective. Based on the results of the systematic review and meta-analysis, the study found medium effect sizes of automation design factors on collaboration task performance (hit rates). These factors included automation transparency, automation reliability, and autonomy level. They also had an impact on workload. Additionally, subgroup analyses showed that these design factors had differential effects on automation trust as well as situation awareness. The study also used a Bayesian network meta-analysis to demonstrate the influence of a wider range of design factors for HAT systems, highlighting the importance of automation transparency as well as automation reliability, and simultaneously indicating that integrating the multiple factors is necessary to improve HAT performance. The research identifies and evaluates the influencing factors of cyber-physical human systems, especially human-centered design factors in the systems, and provides theoretical support for the development of future intelligent industrial systems.

title: Design and Optimization of a Pulsed Fluidized Bed to Prevent Feed Clogging in Fused Granular Fabrication Additive Manufacturing
affiliations: University of Michigan-Dearborn, University of Michigan-Dearborn, University of Michigan-Dearborn, University of Michigan-Dearborn, University of Michigan-Dearborn and University of Michigan-Dearborn

detail.title: Design and Optimization of a Pulsed Fluidized Bed to Prevent Feed Clogging in Fused Granular Fabrication Additive Manufacturing
detail.abstract: This study introduces a novel pulsed fluidized bed approach to avoid material clogging for fused granular fabrication (FGF), an additive manufacturing method that can mechanically recycle thermoplastics in the form of smooth pellets, rough granules, and flat flakes into 3D printed objects. FGF machines face the challenge of inconsistent molten polymer flow due to feedstock clogging before the screw extruder. An automated system was developed to regularly break up feed line clogs using compressed air. Prolonged fluidization of particles in the feed line also causes failure to feed the extruder, so an approach of intermittent, or pulsed, fluidization was developed with most feeding by gravity between pulses. System operation is parametrized by air pressure, airflow, duty cycle, and pulse width. System performance was evaluated on a GigabotX 2 XLT Beta FGF machine for two feeding conditions with recycled poly(lactic acid) (PLA): 1) granules and 2) mixed granules with flakes. Using a fixed pulse width of 2 seconds, a full factorial experimental design was used to investigate the effect of three parameters (air pressure, airflow, and duty cycle) on polymer flow. The pressure and airflow settings that give stable fluidization differed little for the two feedstocks. For the mixed feedstock, a response model captured factor interactions with an R-squared value of 92%. Using optimized operating parameters of 30 psi (210 kilopascals), 3.5 CFM (5.9 cubic meters per hour), and 28.5% duty cycle, the FGF system operated for over 60 hours using mixed granule and flake feedstock without polymer flow discontinuities.

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence and Fossil Fuel Corporate Speech: Who Handle the Truth?
