detail.abstract: Do analytical tools driven by artificial intelligence (AI) empower legal reasoning and analysis in energy transition? The prevalence of hallucinations in AI-assisted legal reasoning and the existed climate misinformation absorbed by large language models add to the uniqueness of this question. As AI-generated materials increasingly shape legal decision-making and knowledge acquisition, this issue becomes closely intertwined with the social construction of truth regarding what energy transition means in climate change mitigation. This Article sheds new empirical and theoretical light on this issue through an original study on fossil fuel corporate speech. We tested a controversial topic in energy practice: is the climate denialism from fossil fuels protected free speech or fraudulent advertising? Current large language models can distinguish honest speech from heavily advertised materials in knowledge-based law school teaching style questions. However, even prompted properly and inputted with abundant First Amendment Jurisprudence knowledge, current large language models showed low performance in (1) identifying well-known fossil fuel industry climate denial strategies; (2) choosing the proper test to scrutiny and reasoning in climate change denial scenarios. We argue that, outside the basic law school training, heavily relying on AI in fossil fuel corporate speech analysis is both doctrinally unreliable and impractical. When presented in polished legal language, these errors risk misleading non-specialist audiences and embedding biased assumptions into the shared doctrinal framework of climate law and attribution science. We further use these results to develop a theory of AI-assisted corporate speech analysis, which firstly calls for vigilance against AI-generated contents and assets that in the initial stage, the application of AI is likely to remain limited and segregated in separated and sequenced scenarios. We conclude reliable AI-enabled corporate speech analysis in energy sector will take time, as current models upgrade into a stage where AI could hold consistent values and the models themselves process findings from attribution science as well as legal research. Finally we offer a pragmatic method to develop curated legal analysis on this issue and a typology for potential AI-lead misunderstanding and deviations for future research.

title: A Necessary and Sufficient Condition for Weighted  Shapley Values in the Core
affiliations: Guangdong University of Foreign Studies and Guangdong University of Foreign Studies

detail.title: A Necessary and Sufficient Condition for Weighted  Shapley Values in the Core
detail.abstract: Very recently,  Skoda and  Venel\citet{SV23} introduced a sufficient condition, called the weighted average-convexity,  to ensure that the weighted Shapley value lies in the core.  In this note, we provide a condition that directly connects the Skoda-Venel condition to the coalitional rationality of the weighted Shapley value. As a by-product, our condition is sufficient and necessary.  This gives a new proof of Skoda-Venel's theorem.   It seems to be the first result on the sufficient and necessary condition to ensure that the weighted Shapley value is in the core.

title: Disclosure Management: Evidence from Regulatory Threshold Avoidance
affiliations: University of Wisconsin-Madison - Department of Accounting and Information Systems, University of Texas at Austin, Ohio State University (OSU) - Department of Accounting & Management Information Systems and Texas A&M University

detail.title: Disclosure Management: Evidence from Regulatory Threshold Avoidance
detail.abstract: In November 2020, the SEC updated the regulation for risk factor disclosures to require a summary if that disclosure exceeds 15 pages. This change aimed to improve the disclosure's usefulness to investors but created legal uncertainty. In response, many firms shortened the disclosure to avoid the summary. Firms are more likely to shorten risk factor disclosures if they recently received an SEC comment letter unrelated to risk factors or have a powerful general counsel. While some firms only altered formatting, most cut sentences and/or words, with some eliminating entire risk factors. These changes imply firms view the summary as costly, even though descriptive tests indicate the summary appears unlikely to help investors. Firms that cut disclosure length to avoid the summary receive fewer SEC comment letters, implying these reductions helped firms avoid legal scrutiny. Collectively, many risk factor disclosures appear less useful, which is contrary to the SEC's objective.

title: Predictive Modeling of Targeted Improvements for County-Level Hpv Vaccine Delivery in South Carolina
affiliations: Xavier University, Medical University of South Carolina - Department of Public Health Sciences, Medical University of South Carolina, Clemson University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Medical University of South Carolina, Xavier University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Medical University of South Carolina

detail.title: Predictive Modeling of Targeted Improvements for County-Level Hpv Vaccine Delivery in South Carolina
detail.abstract: Introduction: Vaccines are vital in preventing communicable diseases. This study compared HPV vaccination rates in two demographically similar states with differing vaccination coverage. Our goal was to uncover variability contributing to HPV vaccination success in one state that could be implemented in the under-vaccinated counterpart. Specifically, the study focused on immunization registry data to develop a predictive model for more efficient county-level resource allocation in South Carolina.Methods: We conducted a cross-sectional study using 2015-2019 secondary data from the American Community Survey and state health departments. The sample included adolescents aged 12-18 in South Carolina, assessing vaccination rates alongside demographic factors.Results: Using negative binomial regression, we developed predictive models for HPV vaccination coverage in South Carolina, based on Georgia data, and compared predicted rates to observed rates. Interestingly, the best-fitting model for South Carolina focused on a single subsequent year, suggesting the importance of timely, year-specific intervention strategies. Differences between observed and predicted vaccination rates were most evident in the counties of Charleston, Greenville, and Richland. These differences indicated the need for targeted strategies to address large discrepancies between predicted and observed vaccination coverage.Conclusions: Local-level predictive modeling can highlight county specific disparities missed by state or national data. By pinpointing areas with substantial gaps, public health officials and primary care providers can tailor interventions to improve vaccination coverage. This predictive modeling method can be replicated in areas with low vaccination coverage and limited data to enhance immunization efforts and ultimately strengthen public health outcomes and cancer prevention.

title: A Review of Machine Learning Models and Algorithms for Short-Term Forecasting of Multi-Energy Consumption in Buildings
affiliations: Institute of General Energy of NAS of Ukraine, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Institute of General Energy of NAS of Ukraine

detail.title: A Review of Machine Learning Models and Algorithms for Short-Term Forecasting of Multi-Energy Consumption in Buildings
detail.abstract: This article presents a comprehensive study aimed at advancing energy consumption forecasting through a meticulous systematic review of existing literature on machine learning techniques. The review synthesizes current methodologies, highlighting their strengths, limitations, and interdisciplinary applications in multi-energy forecasting, while identifying gaps that hinder precision and adaptability in dynamic environments. Addressing these deficiencies, an innovative and versatile forecasting framework is proposed and designed to accommodate the diverse energy sources prevalent in building energy supply systems, such as electrical and thermal inputs. Central to this framework is the introduction of a novel hybrid machine learning model, specifically tailored for short-term energy consumption forecasting. This model integrates advanced deep learning techniques, combining Long Short-Term Memory networks, Convolutional Neural Networks, Gradient Boosted Decision Trees and Transformers with a broad spectrum of data inputs, including historical consumption patterns, weather forecasts, air quality metrics, indoor conditions, and newly proposed indicators like traffic load and transport speed as hypothetical influence factors. By prioritizing adaptability in the training process through a dynamic, iterative pipeline, the model ensures responsiveness to evolving energy use patterns, surpassing the limitations of traditional static approaches. Results from the systematic analysis and model implementation can demonstrate significant potential of improvements in forecasting accuracy and flexibility, enabling precise predictions for both electrical energy usage and thermal comfort requirements across various building types. This research introduces a practical, scalable solution for real-world energy management challenges, contributing to the broader goals of resource efficiency and sustainable development in urban settings.

title: Digital Twin Driven Pavement Deterioration Forecasting: Explainable Route Level Predictions from Automated Survey Data
affiliations: University of Birmingham, University of Birmingham, University of Nottingham and University of Birmingham

detail.title: Digital Twin Driven Pavement Deterioration Forecasting: Explainable Route Level Predictions from Automated Survey Data
detail.abstract: Maintaining aging road networks on limited budgets presents a critical challenge for highway authorities. Traditional pavement management systems often overlook complex underlying deterioration causes, and struggle with analytical integration of diverse data sources. We propose a novel Digital Twin based methodology for predictive pavement deterioration modelling at the route level. UK SCANNER automated condition survey data is enriched with context from GIS datasets, and a robust preprocessing pipeline, incorporating spatial clustering and maintenance history, cleans and segments the survey events into stable analytical units. An XGBoost regression framework is employed to predict rutting, texture depth, and longitudinal profile variance, demonstrating superior performance over a linear baseline for all deterioration metrics. Key findings are that the model accuracy approaches or exceeds the calibration sensitivity of the survey equipment, and that model training data and configurations are largely transferrable between failure modes. Shapely Additive Explanation analysis reveals the dominance of historic condition values for informing future predictions, whilst providing engineering aligned insights into the influence of subtle contextual factors, such as crossfall and traffic flows. The explainable nature of the methodology enhances trust and supports compliance with emerging AI regulations for critical infrastructure, and the approach offers practical utility for operational highway management by providing granular, interpretable, and accurate deterioration forecasts.

title: From Burden to Benefit: Esg's Role in Mitigating Corporate Tax Stickiness
affiliations: Jinan University, Shantou University and Dept. of Economics, Jinan University

detail.title: From Burden to Benefit: Esg's Role in Mitigating Corporate Tax Stickiness
detail.abstract: Excessive taxation can hinder corporate productivity and curtail investment, posing challenges to economic growth. Despite tax reduction policies in China, many enterprises perceive a heavy tax burden, primarily due to tax stickiness—a phenomenon where taxes do not decrease proportionally with declining profits. This study examines the impact of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) performance on corporate tax stickiness using data from Chinese A-share listed companies between 2009 and 2022. Our analysis reveals that enhanced ESG performance significantly reduces tax stickiness. Robustness checks and treatments for endogeneity confirm these findings. Additionally, the mitigating effect of ESG is more pronounced in state-owned enterprises, firms with strong internal controls, and technologically advanced companies. We identify three mechanisms through which ESG alleviates tax stickiness: enhancing bargaining power, reducing agency problems, and alleviating financing constraints. Importantly, improvements in ESG that reduce tax stickiness are associated with increased firm profitability. These findings offer valuable insights into mitigating the perceived tax burden for corporations and guiding national tax administration, while highlighting the broader benefits of ESG engagement.

title: Assessing the Potential Supply Risk Mitigation Due to Public Policies: Application of the Geopolrisk Method to Critical Raw Materials in the EU
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Bordeaux and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Assessing the Potential Supply Risk Mitigation Due to Public Policies: Application of the Geopolrisk Method to Critical Raw Materials in the EU
detail.abstract: Various countries evaluate critical raw materials (CRM) to pilot strategic sectors and inform policy. This contribution evaluates the impact of policies on the supply risk of CRM focusing on the CRM Act benchmarks determined by the European Commission. Based on these benchmarks, we employ the GeoPolRisk method to estimate the potential risk mitigation attainable within the capacity limits of the EU.Mitigation strategies for a first group of CRM are limited to recycling technologies due to a restricted international market and limited reserves. Current practices in the EU for a second group require moderate improvements to attain the benchmarks. The cases of two last CRM show the need for mixed strategies.The analysis is limited by the data required for the assessment; specifically for REE, the application could improve if detailed data becomes available. Future application at intermediate stages in the chain could also reveal bottlenecks in the transformative industry.

title: Estimation of Nonlinear Effects of the Fed's Interest Rate Policy Using the Generalized Propensity Score
affiliations: Magyar Nemzeti Bank

detail.title: Estimation of Nonlinear Effects of the Fed's Interest Rate Policy Using the Generalized Propensity Score
detail.abstract: This study presents a novel methodology for investigating the effect of the Fed's interest rate decisions on the key macro variables. The estimator is based on the generalized propensity score. The main advantage of using the generalized propensity score is the reduction of dimensionality, which facilitates the estimation of nonlinear effects, even from short time series. The key result is that monetary policy has a faster and larger impact on GDP and consumer prices when the interest rate is high. However, the effects of rate hikes and cuts do not show significant asymmetry.

title: A Data Imputation and Parametric Modeling Framework for Building System Material Stock Estimation Under Data Scarcity: Method Development and Application to Switzerland
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and ETH Zürich

detail.title: A Data Imputation and Parametric Modeling Framework for Building System Material Stock Estimation Under Data Scarcity: Method Development and Application to Switzerland
detail.abstract: Reliable estimation of building system material stock is essential for sustainable resource management and circular economy (CE) planning. However, fragmented and incomplete data present significant challenges, particularly in national building stock studies. This research introduces an Integrated Stock Estimation Framework (ISEF) that combines machine learning-based data imputation with expert-driven parametric modeling to estimate material stocks for mechanical, electrical, and plumbing (MEP) components without requiring high-resolution building data. It incorporates temporal and typological variations and demonstrates consistent internal performance across key variables. The case application to Switzerland demonstrates the framework’s capacity to generate scalable material stock estimates under data scarcity. Material flow analysis and scenario-based projections further demonstrate the framework’s ability to map system-specific material use and explore potential resource availability over time. While uncertainties remain due to inherent data limitations, the framework offers a robust basis for advancing material stock modeling methodologies and supporting future research as data availability improves.

title: Book Review: Radical Securities Law
affiliations: Chicago-Kent College of Law - Illinois Institute of Technology

detail.title: Book Review: Radical Securities Law
detail.abstract:
This paper examines Paddy Ireland's book "Property in Contemporary Capitalism" and its challenge to conventional understandings of property law, wealth concentration, and modern capital markets. Ireland argues that modern property rights—particularly those linked to capital assets like stocks, debt instruments, and intellectual property—are not static entitlements but legal claims on future income produced by others. Rather than protecting ownership, property law actively constructs it, transforming property from dominion over things into a contested terrain of social relations and political power.

The paper makes two novel contributions building on Ireland's framework. First, it connects Ireland's theory of property-as-capital to the contemporary dismantling of the administrative state, arguing that efforts to weaken regulatory institutions are central to preserving legal conditions that enable rent extraction. The state no longer merely protects existing property rights but actively constructs new forms of property optimized for extracting value from workers, communities, and the environment.

Second, the paper links Ireland's work to emerging scholarship on movement law and emancipatory legal change. It proposes that rethinking property in relational and democratic terms opens new paths for non-reformist reforms in corporate and securities law—reforms that empower communities and workers rather than merely constraining capital.

The paper proceeds in two parts: Part I introduces Ireland's critique of modern property regimes and situates it within property theory debates; Part II explores how law might support more democratic economic arrangements, drawing on movement law and political economy to imagine alternative legal frameworks where ownership serves collective life rather than private accumulation.

title: Moving Beyond Circular Utopia and Paralysis: Accelerating Business Transformations Towards the Circular Economy
affiliations: Maastricht School of Business and Economics, The University of Manchester - Manchester Business School, Lappeenranta-Lahti University of Technology (LUT) - LUT School of Business and American University - Kogod School of Business

detail.title: Moving Beyond Circular Utopia and Paralysis: Accelerating Business Transformations Towards the Circular Economy

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
declarations.funderStatement: The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: Nancy Bocken has received funding from the European Union’s Horizon 2020 European Research Council (ERC) funding scheme under grant agreement No 850159 (project Circular X)

detail.abstract: The circular economy constitutes a paradigm shift which has proven to be both engaging and unrealistic. While scholars and practitioners have started to advocate for a move toward the circular economy, promising a full reconfiguration of underlying practices and processes, many have become disillusioned about the lack of traction and progress. The circular economy transition has fallen between utopia and paralysis. This article discusses circular utopia and paralysis from a social-symbolic perspective, examining discursive, relational, and material inflators and impediments of the circular economy transition, and the business transformations that have been pursued to navigate within the pragmatic in-between state. We develop a Circular Economy Business Transformation Framework, which assesses how organizations can combat utopia or overcome paralysis and subsequently position the special issue papers within it. We conclude with an agenda for future research aimed at finding pragmatic and actionable, yet significant, business transformations toward the circular economy.

title: Cultures for Innovation
affiliations: McGill University (Desautels) and University of Cambridge - Judge Business School

detail.title: Cultures for Innovation
detail.abstract: We examine how an organization can align its strategic objectives with its innovation culture. Where innovation culture varies according to the targets that are set, the autonomy that exists, and the tolerance management has for failed experiments. Recognizing that organizational culture varies, we build a model of a relational contract where a principal delegates the execution of a derivative and a novel innovation to an expert agent. Given a set of cultural traits, we determine the level of novelty that a principal could pursue. We then analyze how the principal may use their ability to influence culture in pursuit of the novel innovation that forms their strategic objective. We confirm that tolerance for failure can be beneficial to enable novel initiatives, but our results also provide an alternative, cautionary view of tolerance for failure: pursuit of the most novel innovations may require tolerating less failure. We verify that setting targets to constrain the amount of derivative innovation in the portfolio may increase the rate of novel innovation and reduce the likelihood that projects are terminated. We further extend our analysis to examine benefits of target setting and the principal's decision over cultural traits. For managers, we make specific recommendations to map organizational culture to successful innovation.

title: AI Challenges in Mathematical Investing
affiliations: Cornell University - Operations Research & Industrial Engineering, Abu Dhabi Investment Authority

detail.title: AI Challenges in Mathematical Investing
detail.abstract: Investing can be viewed as a complex data science problem. However, general-purpose AI approaches often fall short in investment practice. This seminar explores the key reasons why various mathematical and AI-driven methods fail in the context of investing, and it offers insights into how these challenges can be mitigated.

title: When Speaking Freely Pays: Anti-SLAPP Laws and Firms' Cost of Equity
affiliations: University of Tennessee, University of Tennessee and Huazhong University of Science and Technology - School of Management

detail.title: When Speaking Freely Pays: Anti-SLAPP Laws and Firms' Cost of Equity

publicationDetails.detailsText: European Corporate Governance Institute – Finance Working Paper No. 1078/2025
publicationDetails.journalName: European Corporate Governance Institute (ECGI) - Finance Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: A fundamental question in corporate finance is whether a firm's cost of equity (COE) is influenced more by the amount of information disclosed or by the direction and tone of that information. While greater transparency can reduce information asymmetry and lower financing costs, negative disclosures may increase perceived risk and, consequently, firms' COE. We examine this trade-off using the adoption of U.S. state anti-SLAPP laws, which provide speech protections to corporate critics, thereby promoting the freer flow of information and negative disclosures. Employing an imputation-based difference-indifferences approach, we find that anti-SLAPP laws reduce firms' COE, especially for those in opaque information environments or with better-informed employees. Further analysis suggests that this effect operates through declines in information asymmetry, return volatility, and systematic and stock price crash risk. Our findings highlight how legal institutions that encourage free speech can lower financing costs by enhancing transparency and reducing uncertainty in capital markets.

title: ResTech y resolución de infraestructuras financieras críticas: una aplicación a las entidades de contrapartida central
affiliations: Comisión Nacional del Mercado de Valores (CNMV) and Comisión Nacional del Mercado de Valores (CNMV)

detail.title: ResTech y resolución de infraestructuras financieras críticas: una aplicación a las entidades de contrapartida central

publicationDetails.journalName: CNMV - Spanish Securities & Markets Commission Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Spanish Abstract: Este documento analiza el potencial de la resolution technology (ResTech) como herramienta estratégica para mejorar la planificación, ejecución y seguimiento de los procesos de resolución de entidades de contrapartida central (ECC). Partiendo del ecosistema tecnológico existente en los ámbitos del RegTech y SupTech, se plantea una extensión natural de estas tecnologías a funciones críticas de resolución, en un contexto de creciente digitalización e interconexión financiera. A través de una revisión de literatura y de experiencias institucionales, se identifican las tecnologías habilitadoras más relevantes (como inteligencia artificial, NLP, DLT o simuladores digitales), sus posibles aplicaciones en fases preventivas y ejecutivas, y los riesgos asociados a su adopción. El estudio destaca la necesidad de reforzar las capacidades institucionales, desarrollar entornos seguros para la experimentación y fomentar una cooperación internacional —y, en particular, europea— efectiva, a través de foros como el Consejo de Estabilidad Financiera (FSB) o la Autoridad Europea de Valores y Mercados (ESMA). Finalmente, se proponen líneas de actuación orientadas a integrar progresivamente el ResTech en los marcos operativos y regulatorios, con el objetivo de consolidarlo como un pilar clave para una resolución eficaz, legítima y adaptada a los desafíos  del sistema financiero digital.

title: Solving the Interdependence of Weighted Shortest Job First (Wsjf) Variables by Applying Fuzzy Cognitive Mapping (Fcm)
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Guayaquil, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Granada

detail.title: Solving the Interdependence of Weighted Shortest Job First (Wsjf) Variables by Applying Fuzzy Cognitive Mapping (Fcm)
detail.abstract: In agile, adaptive, and hybrid project management, the Weighted Shortest Job First (WSJF) technique is increasingly being used to prioritize the most relevant business opportunities for organizations. However, this decision-making process often involves the evaluation of multiple interconnected factors whose interactions can influence outcomes in unforeseen ways. Traditional decision-making models tend to assume independence between variables for the sake of simplicity and tractability. However, in real-world contexts, variables are rarely operated in isolation. Their interdependence introduces a range of complexities that challenge the validity, robustness, and practical applicability of conventional decision-making tools. The objective of this research is to address the problem of interdependence among WSJF variables. To achieve this, Fuzzy Cognitive Mapping (FCM) will be applied to solve and evaluate the impact and influence of this interdependence during the decision-making process. A relevant finding is that the effectiveness of the decision-making process improves when the interdependence between variables is determined.

title: Digital Workflows for Informed Decision Making in Building Envelope Design: A Systematic Literature Review
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Navarra, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Digital Workflows for Informed Decision Making in Building Envelope Design: A Systematic Literature Review
detail.abstract: Performance-based optimization in the design of building elements has been widely implemented in recent years, driven primarily by energy efficiency and sustainability requirements. To streamline the time-intensive building performance simulation process, heuristic algorithms and machine learning techniques are increasingly being adopted. While several methodologies have been proposed to optimize building envelope (BE) design, a lack of research remains in evaluating the effectiveness of different tools, algorithms and approaches across various design stages or circumstances. This study systematically reviews the different methods and workflows followed by 165 publications. The reviewed papers are disaggregated into design tasks and classified by the stages of the optimization process, the scale of work, the type of variables concerned, the simulation engines used, or the performance analysis accelerators employed, among others. The aim of the research is to understand the logic behind the optimization parameters, objectives or algorithms to frame them in a design methodology. Alternative decision-making processes, types of graphs, or process outputs are also reviewed, considering interaction and real impact on the decision maker or designer. The analysis leads to a specialized matrix that integrates design parameters, data generation and decision making processes, leveraging various AI tools to enhance optimization tasks. The combination of elements within the matrix defines the sequential steps of an optimization problem. This framework establishes a foundation for flexible, user-centered digital workflows that drive improvements in building efficiency and occupant comfort.

title: Selection Hyper-Heuristics for Multi-Objective Portfolio Optimisation Problems
affiliations: University of Plymouth, University of Plymouth and University of Exeter

detail.title: Selection Hyper-Heuristics for Multi-Objective Portfolio Optimisation Problems
detail.abstract: This paper proposes the use of a selection hyper-heuristic for the multi-objective cardinality-constrained portfolio optimisation problem and compares the hyper-heuristic’s performance with standard multi-objective evolutionary algorithms. The portfolio optimisation problem is an asset allocation problem with a trade-off between return and financial risk that becomes NP-hard when cardinality constraints are introduced, i.e., limiting the number of assets or securities in the portfolio. A selection hyper-heuristic is a learning mechanism that functions as a high-level search strategy for selecting predefined low-level heuristics to apply iteratively during the optimisation process. Our methodology combines a low-level heuristic selection strategy, driven by a variant of a choice function algorithm, with the solution selection process employed in NSGA-II. This approach enhances our ability to efficiently choose and apply heuristics for optimisation. In this study, we explain the functionality and behaviour of the hyper-heuristic. Selecting from five mutation heuristics, the algorithm dynamically adapts to the search space to balance exploration and exploitation effectively. We conducted experiments on five financial portfolio benchmark datasets, including the UK FTSE100, using cardinalities K = 2 and K = 5 on a range of numbers of function evaluations. Based on the empirical results, the algorithm appears to perform well and provides insight into selecting a particular heuristic. This approach also indicates the potential for extensive exploration of the solution selection process.

title: Pay the Voter: A Legal, Economic, and Policy Analysis of Financially Incentivizing Political Participation
affiliations: University of California

detail.title: Pay the Voter: A Legal, Economic, and Policy Analysis of Financially Incentivizing Political Participation

publicationDetails.detailsText: California Law Review, Volume 113, June 2025 Pp. 801-846

detail.abstract: This Note explores the idea of paying Americans to cast their ballots as a mechanism to increase electoral participation among lower income voters and rebalance the influence that wealthy Americans have on policy outcomes. The Note begins by exploring the rationale behind the idea, drawing on political science, economic, and legal literature to argue that subsidizing the franchise could help rebalance elected officials' perception of the "median voter" away from the wealthy. The Note hypothesizes that a small dollar incentive, perhaps no more than $20, paid in a municipal election would have a greater incentivizing effect on low-propensity, low-income voters than it would on higher-income voters. Next, the Note explores the legality and constitutionality of paying the voter. When President Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, vote buying became illegal across the United States. Nevertheless, this Note argues that, based on the legislative history of the Act, a government program to incentivize voting would be legal under federal law. Further, neither the First nor the Fourteenth Amendment poses a barrier to such a program, and a local government in California could enact such a program without violating state law. Finally, the Note explores policy design, proposing that policymakers should begin in a local government, provide direct and highly visible subsidies, and allow voters who cast blank ballots to collect a subsidy.

title: Rate-setting for Standard-Essential Patents: International Evidence and Analysis
affiliations: University of Utah - S.J. Quinney College of Law

detail.title: Rate-setting for Standard-Essential Patents: International Evidence and Analysis

declarations.funderStatement: This Report was commissioned by the UK Intellectual Property Office pursuant to a public tender under Project C3198 awarded on November 17, 2023.

detail.abstract:
The UK Intellectual Property Office commissioned this Report to collect and analyze evidence regarding: (1) the creation of a SEP rate setting board to determine (on a non-binding basis) FRAND rates that can be used in SEP negotiations (i.e., on a bilateral basis between a SEP holder and an implementer), and (2) the determination of an aggregate FRAND royalty rate (i.e. total maximum price) for the SEPs covering a particular standard, before or shortly after its publication.

The Report evaluates the feasibility of these policies, and their potential effectiveness in improving price predictability in SEP licensing, whilst maintaining innovation incentives and consumer welfare. Royalty determination and distribution proceedings conducted by rate-setting bodies in a range of industries share similarities with the types of determinations that would be required of a FRAND rate-setting tribunal for SEPs. Namely, multiple parties with divergent interests are involved; the parties are initially permitted to work out an arrangement amongst themselves, but if they cannot, the tribunal’s procedures are activated; and the tribunal is empowered to compel discovery, conduct hearings, and otherwise adduce all relevant evidence. Accordingly, this Report first summarizes, in Part II, the historical and theoretical basis for governmental rate-setting. It then describes in some detail rate-setting procedures in other fields that can offer instructive models for a potential FRAND rate-setting body. These include rate-setting for US interstate transport, one of the first regulated industries and, at certain points in its history, one of the largest; public utilities such as gas, water and electricity; copyrighted works in the UK and US that are subject to compulsory licensing schemes; pharmaceutical products in the UK and US that are subject to price control and regulation, and the statutory interpleader cause of action in the US that enables multiple parties having claims on a single asset pool to petition a court to assess their claims in a single action to divide those assets equitably.

The Report then turns in Part III to current methods of rate-setting for SEPs, including the private setting of aggregate royalty rates by patent pools, and judicial FRAND rate setting in and non-judicial alternative dispute resolution (arbitration and mediation). Part IV then summarizes recent proposals that have been made to establish FRAND rates for SEPs by other means. This includes the European Commission’s proposed EUIPO SEP Competence Centre, which is intended to maintain a database of European SEPs, to check the essentiality of SEPs to the standards under which they are declared on a sampled basis, and to determine, on a non-binding basis, aggregate FRAND royalty rates for all SEPs covering a particular standard, and rates for particular SEPs and SEP portfolios. This section then describes the proposed US Standard Essential Royalty Act (SERA), which would limit the ability of non-US courts from establishing FRAND royalty rates for US SEPs by creating a new US judicial body having the exclusive authority to determine FRAND rates for US SEPs. Next, it addresses a series of SDO and academic proposals concerning group negotiation of aggregate SEP royalty rates and caps, and an academic proposal for an international, non-governmental tribunal for setting aggregate SEP FRAND rates and allocations. This section then summarizes related proposals that may affect FRAND rate-setting, such as ex ante rate disclosure prior to the publication of a final standard, systems for “checking” the essentiality of declared SEPs and systems for checking the validity of declared SEPs. Finally, Part V applies the evidence presented in Parts II, III and IV to the specific features of a FRAND rate-setting system that are the subject of IPO’s inquiry, including its legal and institutional setting, decisional scope, and procedural design aspects.

title: Hybrid Llm-Based Emergency Management with Constraint-Aware Edge Deployment in Intelligent Transportation System
affiliations: University of Salerno and Polytechnic of Milan

detail.title: Hybrid Llm-Based Emergency Management with Constraint-Aware Edge Deployment in Intelligent Transportation System
detail.abstract: This paper introduces emergency large language (LLM) model, a hybrid neuro-symbolic architecture for real-time emergency management in intelligent transportation systems. The framework integrates a transformer-based LLM with symbolic policy enforcement, constraint-aware safety verification, and Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA)-optimized edge deployment. Unlike prior models that separate perception from control or rely solely on centralized inference, emergency LLM enables seamless interpretation of unstructured incident data, real-time policy validation, and decentralized execution via Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) messaging. The model processes emergency reports into structured semantic representations, verifies outputs against expert-defined rules, and deploys validated decisions at the edge to ensure rapid, policy-compliant interventions. Extensive simulations on urban traffic scenarios demonstrate substantial performance gains: incident classification F1-scores exceed 95%, average emergency response times are reduced by up to 39.1%, and congestion levels drop by over 70% post-intervention. Moreover, the system achieves a 98.6% policy compliance rate while maintaining low latency and communication overhead. An ablation study confirms the contribution of each module to accuracy, safety, and responsiveness. These results establish emergency LLM as a scalable, interpretable, and high-performance solution for emergency coordination, bridging the gap between data-driven reasoning and operational safety in next-generation traffic systems.

title: Uneven Modulation for Prime-Numbered Blades and Tonal Noise Reduction Based on the Cosecant Function
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Huazhong University of Science and Technology and Huazhong University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Uneven Modulation for Prime-Numbered Blades and Tonal Noise Reduction Based on the Cosecant Function
detail.abstract: Uneven blade modulation is a crucial method for noise reduction in turbomachinery, with sine and cosine functions being key technologies. However, these methods are limited by prime-numbered blades and restricted angular position exploration. This study addresses these limitations by improving the modulation method based on prime-numbered blade phase angles and introducing the cosecant function as an alternative to sine and cosine functions. Two types of squirrel-cage fans with different blade numbers, modulation functions, amounts, and periods are designed, and their unsteady noise spectra are analyzed. Results indicate that the improved method successfully applies to prime-numbered blades and various modulation functions, reducing constraints on phase angle offsets and enhancing design efficiency. The cosecant function expands the angular position exploration space. In an 11-blade fan, the preferred cosecant modulation scheme reduces sound pressure levels at the fundamental frequency by 2.89 dB and 5.19 dB compared to evenly spaced blades, by 2.16 dB and 3.87 dB compared to sine modulation, and by 1.89 dB and 4.09 dB compared to cosine modulation. Additionally, the second-order harmonic peak is reduced by 16.31% for 11-blade compared to the sine modulation and 23.36% for 13-blade compared to the cosine modulation. This study provides valuable insights for the broader application of uneven modulation technology in noise reduction and engineering.

detail.abstract: Economic countermeasures occupy an increasingly prominent role in the United States' geopolitical competition with nation-state adversaries and malicious non- governmental threat actors. Driven in part by the search for a more nuanced instrument of international confrontation as compared to military interventions, economic sanctions' as implemented in the United States have until recent years served as a blunt instrument of international coercion and deterrence. Designed to effect a change in foreign adversary behavior, sanctions have historically targeted entire countries or broad swaths of an adversarial nation's economy (i.e., Iran, Cuba, North Korea). This Essay proposes modest reform of the US sanctions regime. In short, sanctions regulators and designating authorities should take seriously the assertion that sanctions are intended to effect a change of behavior—they should approach dealings with sanctioned individuals and entities in the manner that US federal prosecutors approach complex criminal cases, proactively seeking the cooperation of strategically selected targets in service of more effective enforcement actions and broader deterrence.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Photovoltaic Farms Harmonising Nature-Based Solutions and Conservation Standards
affiliations: University of Tuscia, University of East London, University of East London, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Tuscia

detail.title: Evaluating the Impact of Photovoltaic Farms Harmonising Nature-Based Solutions and Conservation Standards
detail.abstract: This study introduces a framework that integrates Nature-based Solutions and Conservation Standards to design, manage, and evaluate photovoltaic farms as multifunctional systems. While the transition to photovoltaic energy is essential to address climate change, conventional installations raise environmental concerns. To address these challenges, we developed a harmonised and flexible framework. First, using Miradi Adaptive Management Software, we built a situation model mapping the environmental threats of photovoltaic farm construction and operation, based on Conservation Standards classifications. Second, a scoping review identified best practices for mitigating these threats; these practices were then integrated into the situation model and translated into result chains. The result chain represents our Theory of Change, providing a structured pathway for photovoltaic farm best practices to address intermediate outcomes, conservation targets, ecosystem services, and societal challenges. A set of indicators was selected by cross-analysing the European Nature-based Solutions impact evaluation handbook and the result chain. The proposed harmonised framework supports tailored strategies and adaptive management and is thus flexible across diverse bioregions and stakeholders. Crucially, it contributes to transformative change by repositioning photovoltaic farms from single-purpose infrastructures to Nature-based Solutions that promote sustainable land use, biodiversity, and human well-being, fostering system-wide shifts in planning, governance, and collaboration.

title: Hashcraft: The On-Demand Hash Function Generator Via Ann and its Verifier
affiliations: Chonnam National University and Chonnam National University

detail.title: Hashcraft: The On-Demand Hash Function Generator Via Ann and its Verifier
detail.abstract: Hash functions play a critical role in modern security systems but face growing threats due to increasing computational power and algorithmic advances. If a hash function is compromised, replacing it with a new one is ideal. However, developing secure alternatives is time-consuming and resource-intensive. In this paper, we propose HashCraft, a novel system that rapidly generates secure hash functions by leveraging the inherent uncertainty of artificial neural networks (ANNs). Unlike conventional static hash algorithms, HashCraft supports on-demand, personalized hash function generation, and incorporates its verifier using an avalanche test to ensure the robustness of generated hash functions. Our prototype shows that HashCraft can produce secure hash functions within 20–40 sec, achieving attack resistance comparable to SHA-2/3. Also, we demonstrate its applicability in HMAC, where per-session hash diversification mitigates replay attacks with minimal overhead.

title: Mechanistic Role of Ph in Guar Gum-Induced Flocculation for Bauxite Mine Slurry Clarification
affiliations: Guilin University of Technology, University of South China, Guilin University of Technology, Guilin University of Technology, Xinyang Normal University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Mechanistic Role of Ph in Guar Gum-Induced Flocculation for Bauxite Mine Slurry Clarification
detail.abstract: Guar gum, a prevalent biopolymer, has been extensively utilized for the separation of slurry suspensions, with the flocculation process being pH-dependent. Despite its widespread use, the specific influence of pH on the flocculation of slurry remains inadequately understood. This study delves into the impact of pH values on the flocculation effectiveness of guar gum-treated bauxite mine slurry through comprehensive flocculation tests. Concurrently, zeta potential measurements, Fourier transform infrared analysis, and scanning electron microscopy analyses were conducted to elucidate the underlying micro-mechanisms of flocculation. The findings indicate that the guar gum significantly enhances the sedimentation rate of mine slurry particles at pH values of 9 or below. Conversely, at the pH of 11, sedimentation rate is markedly reduced, resulting in the persistence of suspended slurry particles. The optimal sedimentation rate was recorded at a neutral pH of 7. Insights from zeta potential data and SEM imagery suggest that the flocculation process is predominantly governed by the formation of hydrogen bonds between the hydroxyl groups in guar gum molecules and the particle surfaces of the mine slurry. This study provides a crucial understanding of the pH-dependent behavior of guar gum in slurry flocculation, offering valuable insights for optimizing industrial separation processes.

title: Soil Erosion Dynamics in an Urbanised Greater Accra Metropolitan Area
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Soil Erosion Dynamics in an Urbanised Greater Accra Metropolitan Area
detail.abstract: Urban erosion is a growing global phenomenon, yet its impacts on livelihoods in developing countries are rarely studied, especially using multiple analytical methods. This study employed a triangulation of qualitative and quantitative data to assess erosion rates across the landscape and the effects on livelihoods in the Ga Central (commonly known as Santa Maria) and Adentan municipalities within the Greater Accra Metropolitan Area (GAMA) of Ghana. The methods used included Gerlach assessment through field measurements, RUSLE mapping, and interview data on household experiences with erosion in the study communities. The Gerlach assessment showed that erosion rates were approximately four times higher on high grounds (95 t ha-1 yr-1), compared to lowlands (25 t ha-1 yr-1). In terms of land use land cover (LULC) systems, erosion rates followed the pattern: bare lands (169.8) > grasslands (4.6) > forests/woodlands (0.003 t ha-1 yr-1). The RUSLE erosion mapping model showed that 69% of the GAMA had values that were higher than the international tolerant threshold of 5.0 t ha-1 yr-1. Soil quality trends, including properties such as organic matter, structure, and bulk density, were generally inversely correlated with vegetative cover and erosion rates. The study also showed that more than 95% of the households with untarred roads leading to them were affected by erosion. However, the drainage systems in Santa Maria mitigated the impact of erosion in the area.
