title: What Are Empirical Monetary Policy Shocks? Estimating the Term Structure of Policy News
affiliations: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City and International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: What Are Empirical Monetary Policy Shocks? Estimating the Term Structure of Policy News

publicationDetails.detailsText: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City Working Paper No. 25-06
publicationDetails.journalName: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Empirical monetary policy shocks (EMPS) mix information about both current and future policy. Policy news shocks at different horizons have different macroeconomic effects, so quantifying this mix is essential to use EMPS to evaluate theory. To disentangle these shocks, we develop an IV method to estimate the term structure of monetary policy news, which captures how an EMPS affects policy residuals at each future horizon. Applying our method to popular monetary policy shocks, we learn that they do not represent textbook surprises Instead, they mix information about policy at many horizons, and this mix varies depending on how the EMPS is identified. We can use the estimated term structures to construct synthetic shocks with arbitrary term structures and assess their macroeconomic effects. Synthetic surprise interest rate hikes are contractionary with little effect on prices, while long-term forward guidance is deflationary.

title: The Impact of Government Innovation Subsidies on the Resilience of the Manufacturing Industry Chain
affiliations: Minzu University of China and Minzu University of China

detail.title: The Impact of Government Innovation Subsidies on the Resilience of the Manufacturing Industry Chain
detail.abstract: Strengthening the resilience of the manufacturing supply chain is a critical issue for China's progression towards becoming a global manufacturing power. Utilizing data of A-share listed manufacturing firms in Shanghai and Shenzhen from 2015 to 2022, this paper investigates the impact and underlying mechanisms of government innovation subsidies on the resilience of manufacturing supply chains. The results show that government innovation subsidies significantly enhance the resilience of manufacturing enterprises, with technological innovation playing a key mediating role. Further heterogeneity analysis reveals that the effect is more pronounced in the central and western China, regions characterized by a higher level of marketization, and high-tech industries, which reflects the characteristics of resource compensation, increased technology dependence, and policy signal amplification. This research contributes to a deep understanding of the relationship between policy instruments and supply chain resilience, and provides insights references for the formulation and improvement of related policies.

title: Monetary Policy and Labor Income Inequality: The Role of Labor Market Tightness
affiliations: East Tennessee State University

detail.title: Monetary Policy and Labor Income Inequality: The Role of Labor Market Tightness
detail.abstract: Does the impact of monetary policy on labor income inequality depend on labor market tightness? We test this hypothesis using a state dependent local projection approach. Our results indicate that in the linear model, a contractionary monetary policy shock increases labor income inequality, although the increase is delayed and relatively low in magnitude. In the non-linear model, we find that when labor markets are not tight, a contractionary monetary policy shock significantly increases inequality. However, when labor markets are tight, the sign is reversed. We confirm the validity of these results under alternate lag lengths, control variables, identification schemes, threshold values, and definitions of state variable. These findings have significant policy implications as they demonstrate that monetary policy can have vastly different distributional outcomes when we account for labor market tightness.

title: How Reliable are Monetary Policy Shocks in Sign-Restricted SVAR Models?
affiliations: Yonsei University and The University of Sydney

detail.title: How Reliable are Monetary Policy Shocks in Sign-Restricted SVAR Models?
detail.abstract: The use of sign restrictions to identify monetary policy shocks in structural vector autoregression (SVAR) models has garnered significant attention in recent years. In this context, we revisit two influential studies—Uhlig (2005) and Arias et al. (2019)—which offer conflicting conclusions regarding the output effects of contractionary monetary policy shocks. Our analysis seeks to uncover the underlying causes of these discrepancies and evaluate the sensitivity of the results to alternative model specifications. Specifically, we examine four key factors: (i) the influence of rotation priors on posterior inference in sign-restricted SVAR models, (ii) the robustness of findings when employing an alternative algorithm to generate large sets of responses, (iii) the sensitivity of results to variations in identifying restrictions, and (iv) the robustness of conclusions to changes in the monetary policy equation and the inclusion of the Great Moderation.

title: Home Equity's Role in Shaping House Price Dynamics
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Home Equity's Role in Shaping House Price Dynamics
detail.abstract: The reinvestment of home equity may help explain the observed persistence of house price growth, as higher sales prices increase the equity of existing homeowners, thereby fueling their housing demand. In this paper, we propose a stylized method that utilizes macroeconomic data to incorporate this home equity channel into housing market models. Our empirical results show that accounting for households’ accrued home equity significantly improves the accuracy of house price modeling in the Netherlands. We further demonstrate that the home equity channel plays a key role in shaping the price effects of macroeconomic and policy-induced shocks. Overall, our findings underscore the role of home equity as a price accelerator in dynamic housing markets and offer important policy implications for market stability.

title: Monetary Policy and Green Energy: A Trade-Off Perspective
affiliations: Ca Foscari University of Venice

detail.title: Monetary Policy and Green Energy: A Trade-Off Perspective
detail.abstract: This study examines the relationship between monetary policy, represented by the Federal Funds Rate set by the Federal Reserve (Fed), the Volatility Index (VIX), Economic Policy Uncertainty (EPU), the unemployment rate, and renewable energy consumption from 1990 to June 2025. Our findings indicate that although the Fed's main goals are economic stability and growth, its policies unintentionally affect patterns of renewable energy consumption. The empirical estimates we present are robust and consistently show a negative relationship between restrictive economic policies and the use of renewable energy resources. This research highlights a complex trade-off between maintaining financial stability and promoting green objectives, underscoring the challenges policymakers face in balancing these often-conflicting priorities.

title: Familiarity and Systematic Risk
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Familiarity and Systematic Risk
detail.abstract: This paper examines how information familiarity—proxied by company age and analyst coverage—shapes systematic risk. Using 12,250 firms from 93 countries and CAPM betas estimated over five-, three-, and two-year windows, we obtain three main findings. First, company age consistently dampens market exposure: tripling a firm’s age lowers the five-year beta by roughly 0.10, a result confirmed by 2SLS. Second, this effect is asymmetric, reducing upside sensitivity (β+) about three times more than downside sensitivity (β−), implying that investor learning tempers reactions to favorable news while leaving vulnerability to broad market declines largely intact. Third, analyst coverage is state-dependent: it attenuates beta in calm periods but amplifies it during crises, when heightened uncertainty induces herding around widely disseminated signals. In sum, age-based familiarity offers a persistent hedge against systematic shocks, whereas signal-based familiarity interacts with macro conditions, producing horizon-contingent risk profiles.

title: The Impact of Early Pension Withdrawals on Household Finances and Inflation
affiliations: Bank of Estonia

detail.title: The Impact of Early Pension Withdrawals on Household Finances and Inflation
detail.abstract: This paper exploits Estonia’s pension reform in 2021 to examine how a large-scale liquidity shock impacts household finances and inflation. The reform made the second-pillar pension contributions voluntary and allowed early withdrawals before retirement age. One-fifth of contributors withdrew their pension savings as soon as this option became available. Using National Accounts (NA) and Distributional Wealth Accounts (DWA) data from 2013 to 2022, we apply a synthetic differences-in-differences method to assess aggregate-level impacts. We explore the micro-foundation behind the results by applying the Household Finance and Consumption Survey (HFCS) data. The reform led to a rise in deposits alongside a reduction in consumer debt balances. However, there was also a strong response in consumption. The household balance sheet effects declined over a year, while consumption stayed elevated, keeping quarterly inflation 1–2 percentage points higher than it would otherwise have been. Withdrawals were concentrated among contributors with little liquidity, a large outstanding balance of consumer debt and a high MPC, amplifying the reform’s impact on consumption.

title: Research on the Allometric Growth Relationship and Coordination between China's New Urbanization and Electricity Consumption
affiliations: Hunan Normal University and Hunan Normal University

detail.title: Research on the Allometric Growth Relationship and Coordination between China's New Urbanization and Electricity Consumption
detail.abstract: With the development of new urbanization, China's demand for electricity consumption is increasing. Studying the allometric growth relationship and coordination between the two is of great significance for promoting the development of green and low-carbon urbanization. This paper takes 31 provinces, municipalities and autonomous regions in China except Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao as the research objects. Based on the new urbanization index and electricity consumption data, the allometric growth model, bivariate spatial autocorrelation and coupling coordination degree model are used to explore the evolution of the relationship between the new urbanization index and electricity consumption in China 's provinces in a long time series from 1996 to 2019. The research results show that: (1) From 1996 to 2019, China as a whole has evolved from a strong growth type of new urbanization development index to a weak growth type of electricity consumption, and the relative growth rate of electricity consumption has been increasing compared with the relative growth rate of new urbanization. At the provincial level, although China is still dominated by provinces with positive allometric growth, the number of provinces with negative allometric growth has gradually increased, and the provinces' awareness of protecting electricity resources has been continuously improving. (2) In terms of spatial distribution, the new urbanization index and electricity consumption show an overall positive correlation, and the strength of the relationship first increases and then decreases, indicating that the electricity consumption structure has gradually begun to transform towards a green and low-carbon direction.

title: S$^3$Ce-Net: Spike-Guided Spatiotemporal Semantic Coupling and Expansion Network for Long Sequence Event Re-Identification
affiliations: Dalian University of Technology, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian University of Technology and Dalian University of Technology

detail.title: S$^3$Ce-Net: Spike-Guided Spatiotemporal Semantic Coupling and Expansion Network for Long Sequence Event Re-Identification
detail.abstract: In this paper, we leverage the advantages of event cameras to resist harsh lighting conditions, reduce background interference, achieve high time resolution, and protect facial information to study the long-sequence event-based person re-identification (Re-ID) task.To this end, we propose a simple and efficient long-sequence event Re-ID model, namely the Spike-guided Spatiotemporal Semantic Coupling and Expansion Network (S$^3$CE-Net). To better handle asynchronous event data, we build S$^3$CE-Net based on spiking neural networks (SNNs).The S$^3$CE-Net incorporates the Spike-guided Spatial-temporal Attention Mechanism (SSAM) and the Spatiotemporal Feature Sampling Strategy (STFS).The SSAM is designed to carry out semantic interaction and association in both spatial and temporal dimensions, leveraging the capabilities of SNNs.The STFS involves sampling spatial feature subsequences and temporal feature subsequences from the spatiotemporal dimensions, driving the Re-ID model to perceive broader and more robust effective semantics. Notably, the STFS introduces no additional parameters and is only utilized during the training stage.Therefore, S$^3$CE-Net is a low-parameter and high-efficiency model for long-sequence event-based person Re-ID.Extensive experiments have verified that our S$^3$CE-Net achieves outstanding performance on many mainstream long-sequence event-based person Re-ID datasets. Code is available at: https://github.com/Mhsunshine/SC3E_Net

title: Sqp-Based Optimization Algorithm: A Novel Calculation Analysis for Improved Energy-Economic Efficiency and Co2 Purity In Stripper Segments Of Ccus Systems
affiliations: Yangtze University, Yangtze University, Yangtze University, Yangtze University and University of Regina

detail.title: Sqp-Based Optimization Algorithm: A Novel Calculation Analysis for Improved Energy-Economic Efficiency and Co2 Purity In Stripper Segments Of Ccus Systems
detail.abstract: This study investigates the effect of stripper segment configuration on CO2 purity, reboiler energy consumption, and overall economic performance in a  post-combustion carbon capture (PCC) process. In this work, a detailed ratebased rigorous model was developed using chemical simulation software, incorporating industrially relevant thermodynamic and hydraulic constraints. Segment numbers were systematically varied across nine cases: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 70, 80, 90, and 100. The Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP) algorithm was implemented in Fortran and externally coupled with the chemical simulation software via a sequential iterative loop. It was applied to minimize reboiler duty and operational cost, subject to process constraints including absorber lean loading, solvent circulation rate, and product purity specifications. The simulation and optimization results revealed that increasing the number of stripper segments improves CO2 desorption performance, with the 100-segment configuration achieving the highest capture efficiency of 99.87% and a lean solvent loading of 0.488 molCO2/molMEA. However, this performance gain is accompanied by increased equipment height and capital investment. SQP successfully identified optimal operating conditions, particularly for pressure, reboiler temperature, and lean solvent conditions that balance energy savings with cost-effectiveness.

title: Measuring Inflationary Pressures in Turkey during the Transition to Inflation Targeting
affiliations: Meliksah University and Vanderbilt University - College of Arts and Science - Department of Economics

detail.title: Measuring Inflationary Pressures in Turkey during the Transition to Inflation Targeting
detail.abstract: This study provides a detailed quantitative analysis of a transition to inflation targeting with a focus on the role of expectations. We investigate the impact of the Turkish central bank's inflation reduction programs on inflation in Turkey from 1996 to 2005. Over this period, there was a transition from non-targeting to semi-formal targeting, and finally, to full-fledged inflation targeting. To analyze the effectiveness of Turkish monetary policy quantitatively, a structural model of the Turkish economy that allows for structural breaks is estimated under the alternative assumptions of rational expectations and adaptive learning. Using these estimates, counterfactual experiments are conducted to obtain ex-ante and ex-post inflation pressure measures that characterize, respectively, the pre-policy and post-policy inflationary environment. The inflation pressure indices indicate that there was no significant difference between the inflationary environments in the 2002-2005 period compared to the 1996-2001 period. However, the monetary policy effectiveness index shows that the semi-formal inflation targeting program implemented from 2002-2005 was considerably more successful in reducing inflation than the policies in the previous period.

title: Robust Deep Network Learning of Nonlinear Regression Tasks by Parametric Leaky Exponential Linear Units (Lelus) and a Diffusion Metric
affiliations: N/A

detail.title: Robust Deep Network Learning of Nonlinear Regression Tasks by Parametric Leaky Exponential Linear Units (Lelus) and a Diffusion Metric
detail.abstract: This document proposes a parametric activation function (ac.f.) aimed at improving multidimensional nonlinear data regression. It is a established knowledge that nonlinear ac.f.’s are required for learning nonlinear datasets. This work shows that smoothness and gradient properties of the ac.f. further impact the performance of large neural networks in terms of overfitting and sensitivity to model parameters. Smooth but vanishing-gradient ac.f.’s such as ELU or SiLU have limited performance and non-smooth ac.f.’s  such as RELU and Leaky-RELU further impart discontinuity in the trained model. Improved performance is demonstrated with a smooth “Leaky Exponential Linear Unit”, with non-zero gradient that can be trained. A novel diffusion-loss metric is also proposed to gauge the performance of the trained models in terms of overfitting.

title: Financially Constrained Households and Consumption Volatility in Open Economies
affiliations: Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México (ITAM) and ITAM

detail.title: Financially Constrained Households and Consumption Volatility in Open Economies
detail.abstract: Emerging market economies often exhibit aggregate consumption that is more volatile than aggregate income, contrary to predictions of standard macro models that are based on consumption smoothing through financial markets under transitory productivity shocks. This paper explores whether heterogeneity in access to financial services can explain this excess consumption volatility. To this end, we extend the standard SOE-RBC model by incorporating both financially constrained and unconstrained households, alongside procyclical firm entry dynamics. Calibrated to capture emerging market features, the model successfully generates greater aggregate consumption volatility compared to aggregate income even when the only source of fluctuations is a transitory productivity shock. Using this framework, we conduct a Bayesian estimation on macroeconomic data for 12 advanced, 17 emerging, and 11 low-income economies. This comprehensive estimation delivers the macro-data consistent fraction of financially constrained households in each country, which aligns closely with the micro-data.

title: Balanced Budget Requirements and Local Austerity Multipliers
affiliations: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, Organization for Economic Co-Operation and Development (OECD) - Economics Department (ECO) and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Balanced Budget Requirements and Local Austerity Multipliers
detail.abstract: Fiscal consolidation often entails balanced budget requirements (BBRs) imposed to local governments. However, little is known about the effects of BBRs on economic activity, as most quasi-experimental estimates of local fiscal multipliers stem from windfall expansionary shocks. This paper studies the 2013 extension of a BBR to Italian municipalities below 5,000 residents. Using a two-stage least squares difference-in-discontinuities design, we document that tighter rules pushed local governments to increase their budget surplus and correspondingly reduce their borrowings by about 1% of residents’ income. Treated municipalities cut capital expenditures, rather than decreasing current expenditures or raising taxes. The estimated local fiscal multiplier is not statistically different from zero and significantly lower than 1.5, even after accounting for spatial and public procurement network spillovers. Overall, our findings point to a relatively low short-term local output cost of BBRs.

title: Food Waste: You Can't Always Want What You Get
affiliations: Paris School of Economics, CY Cergy Paris Université and Bilkent University

detail.title: Food Waste: You Can't Always Want What You Get
detail.abstract: Food waste constitutes a significant economic inefficiency and should therefore be a central policy issue. While in low-income countries food waste is often associated with poor harvesting, storage and transportation conditions, in middle- and high-income countries consumers' behavior is considered to be the main driver of this problem. The general aim of our paper is to contribute to the understanding of food waste. We focus on household food waste and the economic mechanisms behind it. We propose a stylized model in which food waste appears as an economic decision of households. Our framework of "rational food waste" relies primarily on consumer behavioural biases, which could be further encouraged by aggressive pricing strategies such as quantity discounts.

title: The Shape of U - on the Structure  of Utility \\ from Electric Vehicle Charging
affiliations: University of Cologne

detail.title: The Shape of U - on the Structure  of Utility \\ from Electric Vehicle Charging
detail.abstract: With the growing adoption of electric vehicles, understanding user charging behavior is increasingly important for informing operational, investment, and policy decisions regarding their integration into the power system. While utility functions are commonly used to describe user preferences in charging behavior models, most existing studies rely on formulations with limited theoretical consistency and empirical validation, potentially leading to biased expectations.This paper empirically compares different utility function specifications and examines their implications for charging behavior modeling and charging station profitability.I introduce a novel discrete choice model framework to efficiently estimate utility function parameters from revealed preference data. Using a dataset of observed charging sessions at public charging stations in Germany, the model identifies accurate utility functions, uncovers charging preferences, and simulates station segment viability.The results suggest that charging utility is non-linear: marginal utility decreases with charged energy and marginal disutility increases with charging duration. An interaction between energy and duration leads to higher marginal valuation of energy for longer charging durations.  Stations profit from inelastic demand driven by users who highly value energy content, are less price sensitive, and engage in high-value activities at the charging location, such as in urban areas or traffic hubs.

title: Impact of Team Work on Organizational Performance (A Case Study of Financial Institutions in Abuja Nigeria (First Bankplc; Guaranty Trust Bankplc & Zenith Bank PLC)
affiliations: Shell Nigeria LNG, Bonny Island.

detail.title: Impact of Team Work on Organizational Performance (A Case Study of Financial Institutions in Abuja Nigeria (First Bankplc; Guaranty Trust Bankplc & Zenith Bank PLC)
detail.abstract: This study is set out to investigate the "impact of team work on organizational performance". Methodology: Relevant data were drawn from selected staff from selected banks in Abuja, using a well-structured questionnaire. Chi-square was used to check the hypotheses. The result of the findings revealed that there is a significant impact of team change on organizational performance in financial institutions in Abuja, There is a significant relationship between team change and organizational performance in financial institutions in Abuja, there is a significant impact of team effectiveness on organizational performance, there is a significant relationship between team structure and organizational performance in financial institutions. Study conclusion and policy recommendations: The study concluded and established, provided evidence that organizational success depends upon the interdependence recognized within teams and how vital it is for team members to understand their roles and work to achieve corporate goals thus having a positive influence on organizational performance. Finally the study recommends: that the management of financial institutions should promote shared values in the organization through allowing employees to have their expressions and view listened to, this allows the organization to develop a good culture which can be transformed into organizational values and norms. Leaders should trust their subordinated and assign them responsibilities and the subordinates should also trust their superiors. Trust among employees promotes good work relations among them and this leads improved performance which is seen through effectiveness in service delivery.

title: The Impact of Personalised Digital Information on Vehicle Choices in Developing Countries
affiliations: ETH Zürich - CER-ETH - Center of Economic Research at ETH Zurich, ETH Zürich - CER-ETH - Center of Economic Research at ETH Zurich and ETH Zürich - CER-ETH - Center of Economic Research at ETH Zurich

detail.title: The Impact of Personalised Digital Information on Vehicle Choices in Developing Countries
detail.abstract: We assess the value of information provision in enabling potential buyers of vehicles to purchase more energy-efficient options in low-income and low-education contexts. Using a randomised controlled trial in Nepal, we test the impact of personalised information provision using a novel digital platform. Applying stated and revealed preference approaches, we find that providing information on five-year operating cost savings, compared to the fuel economy, improved the efficiency of motorcycles selected by respondents; these effects persisted for individuals who exhibited certain forms of behavioural anomalies. We show that our intervention makes respondents evaluate their purchase decisions more seriously, which has positive private and economy-wide implications.

title: Unpacking Economic Mobility: The Short-and Long-Term Impacts of Trade Liberalization
affiliations: Oklahoma State University and Saint Olaf College

detail.title: Unpacking Economic Mobility: The Short-and Long-Term Impacts of Trade Liberalization
detail.abstract:
Trade liberalization impacts economic growth, inequality, and mobility, typically examined
separately. By breaking down absolute economic mobility into these three areas, we explain how
each component contributed to real per-capita expenditure changes due to tariff reductions.
Using Indonesia's IFLS data, we connect individuals over the short term (1993-2000) and fatherson
pairs over the long term (1993-2014). Our analysis also considers if non-coresident fatherson
pairs behaved differently relative to coresident pairs. Further, we explore if the economically
vulnerable segments were able to participate in the overall patterns experienced by the economy.
We find that tariff reductions fostered absolute economic mobility of real per-capita expenditures
by promoting regional growth, reducing inequality, and enhancing relative economic mobility,
particularly benefiting the individuals and households in the lowest quartile. Over time, regional
disparities in the effects of tariff cuts diminished as regions converged.

title: The Criminal Tribes Act of 1871 and its Global Legacy
affiliations: BASIS International and Basis Independent

detail.title: The Criminal Tribes Act of 1871 and its Global Legacy
detail.abstract:
The Criminal Tribes Act of 1871, imposed by British colonial authorities in India, was a draconian law that branded entire communities as “hereditary criminals,” enforcing systematic surveillance, forced settlement, and social ostracization. This paper provides a comprehensive examination of the Act’s origins, implementation, and enduring legacy. It begins by contextualizing the Act within India’s caste system, tracing how ancient religious codifications – from the Rigveda to the Manusmriti – established and justified a rigid hierarchy that colonial policies later exploited. We analyze the language and intent of the Act, illustrating how the British administration wielded it as an instrument to control nomadic and marginalized groups by presuming criminality by birth. The short-term impacts on Dalits (formerly “Untouchables”), Adivasis (indigenous tribes), and other minorities were severe: communities faced loss of land, curtailed freedoms, and state-sanctioned stigma, with an estimated thirteen million people across 127 communities directly affected by Independence. The Act’s long-term repercussions persisted well beyond its repeal in 1949, as independent India’s Habitual Offenders Act (1952) continued to profile and police these denotified tribes, entrenching cycles of poverty and prejudice.

Crucially, this paper situates the Criminal Tribes Act in a comparative global context. Parallels are drawn to other systems of institutionalized oppression: the Jim Crow laws in the United States, which enforced a codified racial apartheid and denied African Americans basic rights; the internment of Japanese Americans during World War II, whereby ~120,000 people (two-thirds U.S. citizens) were incarcerated without cause; and South Africa’s apartheid regime, which legally classified citizens by race to maintain white supremacy. These comparisons reveal common patterns of using the law to strip targeted groups of rights under the guise of “social order” or “national security.” The paper also examines modern surveillance measures – from preventive detention of Muslims under anti-terror laws to predictive policing technologies – arguing that the underlying logic of collective suspicion echoes the legacy of the 1871 Act in contemporary forms.

Through extensive use of scholarly sources, including archival colonial reports and the writings of historians and anthropologists, as well as eyewitness accounts and recent news reports, we highlight how the narrative of “born criminals” created by the Act remains etched in societal attitudes. We incorporate historical data (caste-based census records, crime statistics) and present-day metrics (crime rates against Dalits, wealth and education disparities by caste) to visualize the enduring impact. Graphs and charts are used to illustrate trends such as the economic marginalization of Dalits and the racial disparities in incarceration that mirror caste inequalities. Ultimately, this study demonstrates that while the Criminal Tribes Act was repealed, its spirit survives in prejudices and legal practices worldwide. It calls for a critical re-examination of laws and social structures that continue to otherize and criminalize marginalized communities, advocating for reforms grounded in equality, restorative justice, and the protection of fundamental rights. The global legacy of the Criminal Tribes Act serves as a cautionary tale of how state power can perpetuate social stratification – and a reminder of the ongoing struggle to dismantle such oppressive systems.

title: Biomass Production of Grasslands: Spatial Distribution of Biomass Production and Feed Demand in Two Contrasting Regions of Bavaria, Germany

detail.title: Biomass Production of Grasslands: Spatial Distribution of Biomass Production and Feed Demand in Two Contrasting Regions of Bavaria, Germany
detail.abstract: AbstractContext For agriculture, biomass production for feeding livestock is an essential ecosystem service of grasslands. In line with the European Green Deal’s farm-to-fork strategy, maximizing fodder production from existing grasslands is more sustainable than relying on high-intensive cropland feed. Reducing imports and dependency on cropland feed is a global environmental goal. However, it remains unclear whether current grassland resources can sufficiently meet livestock’s energy needs.Objective This study assesses the balance of metabolizable energy (ME) from grasslands in two contrasting regions of Bavaria, Germany.Methods We estimate the ME balance per farm and year using data from the Integrated Administration Control System (IACS), including field usage, livestock information, and modeled yield data. We analyze variations between a dry year (2018) and a typical year (2020) under conventional and organic farming.Results and Discussions Results show an average ME deficit of ~1,000 GJ per farm (equivalent to 17 dairy cows) in northern Bavaria, whereas the (pre-)Alpine region in southern Bavaria generally shows surpluses, roughly one potential additional dairy cow per farm (~60 GJ surplus). Within the southern region, a north-south trend appears, with deficits in the north and surpluses in the south. No clear pattern emerges in northern Bavaria. Organic farms tend to exhibit higher ME surpluses than conventional farms. A geographically weighted regression reveals that elevation, precipitation, agri-environmental schemes, and farming practices significantly influence ME balances, with effects varying spatially.Significance These findings underscore the need of region-specific strategies to optimize grassland fodder production and enhance the resilience of livestock farming in a changing climate.

title: From Swords to Syntax: How LLM Agents Cooperate in the Commons With and Without Sanction Mechanisms
affiliations: George Mason University

detail.title: From Swords to Syntax: How LLM Agents Cooperate in the Commons With and Without Sanction Mechanisms
detail.abstract: We replicate Ostrom, Walker, and Gardner's "Covenants with and Without a Sword" experiment using large language model (LLM) agents within a common pool resource (CPR) framework to assess their capacity for cooperative behavior. Employing the LangChain framework, we simulate eight GPT-based agents interacting over 20 rounds under four conditions-baseline (no communication, no sanctions), communication only, sanctions only, and communication with sanction sacross high and low endowment scenarios. Results show that LLM agents achieve near-optimal efficiency (100% by Round 20) when communication and sanctions are combined, mirroring human outcomes in Ostrom et al.'s work. LLM agents also consistently vote to implement sanctions, reinforcing self-governance principles. However, significant deviations emerge: in baseline conditions, LLM agents rapidly adjust to high efficiency (60-89% in high endowment, and 95-100% in low endowment), outperforming humans who struggle with persistent over-allocation (32% and ∼35%, respectively). In communication-only scenarios, LLM agents falter, settling on suboptimal strategies (e.g.,-33.2% efficiency in high endowment) due to an overly prosocial bias, unlike humans who achieve temporary gains (74.1%). Sanctions alone yield variable but improved outcomes (95.2% in high endowment), though agents overuse maximal penalties, lacking the graduated enforcement seen in human subjects. This replication underscores LLM agents' potential as a powerful tool for experimental economics, enabling rapid, scalable simulations, while revealing distinct AI behavioral dynamics-such as rapid learning and excessive agreeableness-that inform AI alignment and autonomous system design.

title: Who Pays? Opportunity Costs of Nature-Inclusive Dairy Farming Practices in the Netherlands

detail.title: Who Pays? Opportunity Costs of Nature-Inclusive Dairy Farming Practices in the Netherlands
detail.abstract: 1. CONTEXTMany farmers face structural constraints and high fixed costs that limit their ability to adopt more extensive milk production strategies or even take land out of production.2. OBJECTIVEThis paper examines the economic trade-offs involved in adopting nature-inclusive farming practices in the Dutch dairy sector by quantifying the opportunity costs associated with implementing measures such as additional grazing days or reductions in external input use, and by examining the circumstances under which these costs arise or vary.3. METHODSUsing data from the Dutch Farm Accountancy Data Network (FADN) and a bio-economic benchmarking model, we quantify these costs.4. RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONSOur findings suggest potential for increased farm income and improved environmental performance through the adoption of nature-inclusive practices, conditional on the implementation of more efficient management strategies. However, achieving such win-win outcomes generally requires greater reliance on capital and finance. When capital cost constraints were relaxed in the model, it favoured less capital-intensive pathways, including more extensive operations with reduced dependence on external variable inputs. Opportunity costs vary substantially across farms, with the highest costs found among those already farming extensively. The findings underscore a critical challenge for policymakers: facilitating the transition to nature-inclusive farming will likely require public compensation mechanisms or new market arrangements to offset foregone income.5. SIGNIFICANCEBy situating the Dutch dairy farming case within broader European sustainability and policy debates, the paper offers insights that are relevant for international efforts to integrate ecosystem service provision into agricultural systems. As farms reduce reliance on variable external input use and intensive production and diversify income streams, societal support will be essential in reshaping market incentives, policy frameworks, and value chain governance.

title: Can Market Competition Help Mitigate Climate Change? Evidence from the Top Ten Manufacturing Countries
affiliations: Tunisian Competition Council

detail.title: Can Market Competition Help Mitigate Climate Change? Evidence from the Top Ten Manufacturing Countries
detail.abstract: Industrialization is one of the principal factors responsible for climate change, as it significantly contributes to increasing pollution and global warming. The intense competition in domestic and international markets fuels the process of industrialization, which raises the question of the extent to which market competition affects climate change. This chapter aims to answer this question by developing a model that explains the relationship between market competition and climate change based on a Cobb-Douglas production function. An empirical study is conducted using a dataset from 2007 to 2019 for a panel of the top 10 manufacturing countries. The feasible generalized least squares method is employed to estimate the proposed model and tackle the problems of cross-sectional dependence, heteroskedasticity, and serial correlation. The climate change performance index is used to assess the performance of countries in terms of climate protection, while market competition is measured by three proxies, namely the import penetration ratio, the extent of market dominance indicator, and the index of economic freedom. The empirical findings provide sufficient evidence of the negative effects of domestic market competition on climate protection in the top 10 manufacturing countries against the positive effects of foreign competition. They also reveal that financial development has a positive effect on climate change mitigation, unlike economic growth and foreign direct investment, which have negative effects. These findings are informative for policymakers to set out competition policies that can help address climate change.

title: Understanding Optimal Currency Structures: A Study of India's Denomination System 1
affiliations: Reserve Bank of India and Reserve Bank of India

detail.title: Understanding Optimal Currency Structures: A Study of India's Denomination System 1
detail.abstract: Currency forms a significant part of an economy's money supply and thus influences the overall standard of living of its citizens. Defining an optimal currency denomination structure by policy makers is essential not only for macroeconomic implications but also for reasons such as ease of transactions by citizens, eradicating counterfeiting and influencing people's perceptions about their wealth and purchasing power. Despite the surge in digital payments, cash remains the dominant mode of transactions in India. The RBI press release dated August 2017 2 mentions that optimal currency structure is the one that will minimize the number of denominations and simultaneously increase the probability of obtaining exact change in transactions of any given amount. Like many other countries India has adopted a near variation of the Renard series and has denominations in the series of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 50, 100, 200, 500 and 2000. There is a significant paucity of research on analyzing the currency denomination structure of India or determining its optimal structure, although a few related studies exist on analyzing factors affecting the structure and demand for currency. There is no research study yet to establish that the prevailing denomination mix satisfies the optimality criteria as described above. This study firstly provides an extensive literature review of the existing associated theories and their applications worldwide. Secondly, the study provides an empirical analysis of the prevailing currency denomination structure in India using the D-Metric Model developed by Dr. L.C. Payne in the late 1980s for determining the coin-tobanknote transition by relating it to the average daily wage level (D) of a country to its currency denomination structure. Most importantly, the study establishes that the prevailing denomination mix of 1:2:2:5 satisfies the first criteria of optimality, i.e. minimizing the token size. Finally, the study shows that a new mix 1:1:3:5 also satisfies the same criteria as defined above.

detail.title: Pumping Station as an Effective Flood Control Project of Valenzuela City
detail.abstract: Flooding affects several low-lying regions in Metro Manila, such as Valenzuela City, and is usually among the worst hit in every series of flooding. Hence, certain low-lying areas are still exposed and deal with flooding. These flooding situations turned into a significant turning point in the Philippine government's commitment to flood control. The pumping station is one such initiative, aimed at mitigating flooding and managing water waste. Thus, this study aims to evaluate the functionality in reducing the frequency, intensity, and contribution to enhancing urban flood resilience. Moreover, this paper employs a mixed-method approach to gain in-depth understanding, knowledge and strengthen the reliability and validity of the information and data gathered. This approach provides comprehensive data that Local Government Units (LGUs) can use to develop the project further. Based on the study, the researchers found out that the pumping stations are very effective flood control project since they will quickly alleviate flooding in a short period of time and continuously operate even when it is not raining. Additionally, the pumping station has the potential to enhance residence safety, beginning with the local government and continuing up to the national level, as long as it continues to manage solid waste since waste can cause malfunction in the pumping station. Concerning this, it is important to establish a policy and program recommendation designed to strengthen the operations of pumping station projects in Valenzuela City.

title: Crackrefinenet: A Context- and Refinement-Driven Convolutional Architecture for Robust Crack Segmentation Under Real-World and Zero-Shot Conditions

detail.title: Crackrefinenet: A Context- and Refinement-Driven Convolutional Architecture for Robust Crack Segmentation Under Real-World and Zero-Shot Conditions
detail.abstract: Accurate segmentation of road cracks is critical for infrastructure monitoring, yet remains challenging due to complex textures, illumination variations, and the thin, fragmented nature of cracks. We propose CrackRefineNet, a novel convolutional architecture that integrates three complementary modules—Context-Aware Modelling, Adaptive Feature Refinement, and Selective Feature Aggregation—to enhance crack localization and boundary precision. Built upon ConvNeXt as a backbone, our method captures fine-grained structures and global semantics by strategically injecting context into early layers and refining features at deeper stages. Aggregated intermediate predictions further guide the final mask generation through a unified decoder. We conduct comprehensive experiments on four benchmark datasets: RCFD, Crack500, CFD, and Sylvie (zero-shot). Our model achieves state-of-the-art performance, surpassing baselines by up to 3.5% IoU and 2.8% F1-score on supervised datasets, and shows strong generalization with 42.91% F1-score and 63.03% mIoU in zero-shot testing. These results confirm CrackRefineNet’s effectiveness, robustness, and practical readiness for real-world pavement inspection.

title: The Socioeconomic Impact of Bantay Estudyante Program on Senior Traffic Aides in Valenzuela City

detail.title: The Socioeconomic Impact of Bantay Estudyante Program on Senior Traffic Aides in Valenzuela City
detail.abstract:
In the Philippines, many senior citizens are facing economic challenges as a result of rising healthcare
costs, limitations on pension benefits, and a lack of job opportunities. To address this issue, the local
government of Valenzuela City established the Bantay Estudyante Program under City Ordinance 318
that employs senior citizens as traffic aides responsible for ensuring the safety of the students near
school zones while also providing the elderly with meaningful employment opportunities. Creating
opportunities at the local government level, such as employment programs, has been a smart approach
to addressing the socioeconomic issues that the elderly confront. This study was focused on assessing
the socioeconomic impact of the Bantay Estudyante Program on the senior traffic aides. Through the use
of five key factors of socioeconomic status: financial stability, health and well-being, job satisfaction,
community involvement and recognition, and skill development, this study was able to analyze the
socioeconomic impact of the program. A mixed methods approach was used in this study in gathering
data through surveys and interviews involving the senior traffic aides and the key informants involved in
the implementation of the program. Findings suggest that the Bantay Estudyante Program was beneficial
in promoting community involvement and skill development among the senior traffic aides. Even though
the Bantay Estudyante Program helps senior citizens to remain active, health and job satisfaction were
moderately observed taking into considerations the challenges and risks in their workplace conditions,
such as exposure to extreme heat from the sun during their tour of duty thus, health security benefit was
also observed. In addition to this, as stated in the ordinance, the allowance received by the senior citizens
traffic aides under the program was regarded as insufficient, impact of inadequate financial stability for
the elders under the program. Therefore, resolving workplace challenges and financial limitations is
crucial to strengthening the program’s initiatives that would benefit senior traffic aides.

detail.abstract: The most widely used textbooks on Introductory Econometrics conflate three distinct population parameters: the population regression function (PRF), the conditional expectation function (CEF), and the causal effect. They also incorrectly suggest, and sometimes state, that the Conditional Mean Zero assumption implies causal interpretation of regression coefficients. I highlight these issues and show that by incorporating new notation these limitations can easily be overcome.

detail.title: Formulating Payment for Ecosystem Services (Pes) Framework for Engineered Environment: A Case Study of the Indonesia Coral Reef Garden (Icrg) in Nusa Dua, Bali
detail.abstract: Indonesia, as the global epicentre of coral reef biodiversity, faces mounting ecological pressures that threaten the sustainability of its marine ecosystems. In response, the Indonesia Coral Reef Garden (ICRG) initiative was launched to restore degraded reefs using artificial structures while simultaneously generating economic benefits through tourism. This study explores the feasibility of implementing a Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES) mechanism to support the long-term sustainability of the ICRG in Nusa Dua, Bali. Using a mixed-methods approach—combining ecological assessment, economic valuation, and stakeholder analysis—the research calculates a PES value of IDR 35,154 (USD 2.13) per visitor. This value is derived from capital costs, estimated asset lifespan, annual maintenance requirements, and the economic value of ecosystem services utilized by visitors. The study situates its findings within global PES experiences from Costa Rica, Mexico, China, Kenya, and Vietnam, highlighting the importance of legal frameworks, community engagement, and technological integration in successful PES implementation. It emphasizes the need for phased financing strategies—beginning with government or donor support and transitioning to user-based payments through mechanisms such as tourism fees, eco-certification, and digital micro-payments. The findings advocate for a participatory, transparent, and adaptive PES model embedded within Indonesia’s marine spatial planning agenda. Ultimately, this study provides a replicable framework for sustainable reef restoration financing, supporting Indonesia’s commitments to marine conservation, climate resilience, and blue economy development.

title: Looking Through the Codebook: Generative Anomaly Segmentation with Multi-Contrastive Learning
affiliations: Korea University, Korea University, Korea University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Inha University and Korea University

detail.title: Looking Through the Codebook: Generative Anomaly Segmentation with Multi-Contrastive Learning
detail.abstract: Most of the existing semantic segmentation models are based on discriminative approaches, which often fail to detect out-of-distribution (OoD) objects. By contrast, generative models use the underlying data distribution, resulting in more effective anomaly detection. Recent methods have integrated generative components into discriminative models rather than adopting purely generative segmentation models. Therefore, we propose an anomaly detection method on a purely generative semantic segmentation model. Specifically, we employ a vector-quantized variational autoencoder to detect anomalies, which encodes images into a categorical latent space of codevectors. By treating the segmentation class-specific codevectors as in-distribution (ID) representations, we introduce a codevector-wise top‑$K$ criterion. This criterion scores each pixel based on its top‑$K$ nearest codevectors and their associated scores, thereby reflecting relative similarities within the same classes. Furthermore, we implement a codevector-based multi-contrastive learning strategy with specially sampled void labels. This implementation effectively structures the latent space among classes and ensures that anomalies are not aligned with ID codevectors. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method detects anomalies effectively and performs robustly in single- and cross-domain scenarios.

title: Feature Discrepancy Guided Score Learning for Few-Shot Anomaly Detection
affiliations: Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing Jiaotong University and Beijing Jiaotong University

detail.title: Feature Discrepancy Guided Score Learning for Few-Shot Anomaly Detection
detail.abstract: Few-shot anomaly detection aims to identify and locate image anomalies using limited normal samples, enabling rapid deployment in industrial and safety applications. However, recent multimodal pre-trained methods often rely on statistical comparisons between query and reference features, which may lead to overlapping anomaly scores due to neglecting normal region interference and local contextual correlations. To address this, we propose the Feature Discrepancy guided Score Learning (FDSL) method. FDSL explicitly models deviations from normal patterns via a Feature Discrepancy (FD) module that separates patch features into normal and deviation components. An Anomaly Score Learning (ASL) module is then introduced to capture feature correlations and integrate neighboring patch information for more discriminative scores. Additionally, a Local-enhanced Feature Extraction (LFE) mechanism improves detection of small-area anomalies, while an image feature index memory bank reduces redundancy to optimize memory usage. Experimental results on MVTec and VisA datasets show that FDSL achieves state-of-the-art performance in 1-shot, 2-shot, and 4-shot segmentation tasks and is competitive in classification, demonstrating its effectiveness and adaptability in few-sample scenarios. The code is available at https://github.com/Follow-winds/FDSL-fewshot-anomaly-detection.

title: You Can Mask More for Extremely Low-Bitrate Image Compression
affiliations: Beijing Jiaotong University, Hefei University of Technology, Beijing Jiaotong University, Shandong University, Beijing Jiaotong University, Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Beijing Jiaotong University and Beijing Jiaotong University

detail.title: You Can Mask More for Extremely Low-Bitrate Image Compression
detail.abstract: Learned image compression (LIC) methods have experienced significant progress in recent years. However, these methods are primarily dedicated to optimizing the rate-distortion (R-D) performance at medium and high bitrates ($>$ 0.1 bits per pixel (bpp)), while research on extremely low bitrates is limited. Besides, existing methods fail to explicitly explore the image structure and texture components crucial for image compression, treating them equally alongside uninformative components in networks. This can cause severe perceptual quality degradation, especially under low-bitrate scenarios. In this work, inspired by the success of pre-trained masked autoencoders (MAE) in many downstream tasks, we propose to rethink its mask sampling strategy from structure and texture perspectives for high redundancy reduction and discriminative feature representation, further unleashing the potential of LIC methods. Therefore, we present a dual-adaptive masking approach (DA-Mask) that samples visible patches based on the structure and texture distributions of original images. We combine DA-Mask and pre-trained MAE in masked image modeling (MIM) as an initial compressor that abstracts informative semantic context and texture representations. Such a pipeline can cooperate well with LIC networks to achieve further secondary compression while preserving promising reconstruction quality. Consequently, we propose a simple yet effective masked compression model (MCM), the first framework that unifies MIM and LIC end-to-end for extremely low-bitrate image compression. Extensive experiments have demonstrated that our approach outperforms recent state-of-the-art methods in R-D performance and visual quality at very low bitrates. Our code is available at https://github.com/lianqi1008/MCM.git.

title: Targeted Poverty Alleviation and Unincorporated Entrepreneurship: Evidence from China
affiliations: University of Nevada, Reno, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Targeted Poverty Alleviation and Unincorporated Entrepreneurship: Evidence from China
detail.abstract: Unincorporated businesses serve as economic lifelines for low-income households when formal jobs are scarce. This study provides the first causal evidence that a large-scale anti-poverty program can promote unincorporated entrepreneurship. We focus on China’s Targeted Poverty Alleviation program, a landmark initiative combining precision targeting with multi-sector interventions. Using a difference-in-difference approach, we examine county-level business registrations (2010-2022) and household survey data (2010-2020). The program significantly increased unincorporated business entry by 6.9% at the county level and raised household business ownership by 2.75 percentage points. Three mechanism drive these gains: spillover from large enterprises, expanded access to credit, and infrastructure improvements. Effects concentrate in counties with stable leadership and moderate corruption and are strongest in agriculture and among poor households, showing that well-governed, targeted interventions can redirect business ownership toward disadvantaged groups. Overall, our findings offer lessons for other low- and middle-income economies seeking to empower marginalized populations through small-scale enterprise.

detail.abstract: With Unconditional Cash Transfers in Agriculture emerging as a significant policy instrument in India in recent years, evaluating such interventions has become imperative and policy relevant. This study aims to estimate the causal impact of one such program implemented by the state of Telangana in 2018, on the agricultural input spending. This study uses the data from the National Sample Survey’ s 77th round, which is a nationally representative survey conducted in 2018-19. The analysis applies propensity score matching combined with inverse probability weighting method to estimate the causal impact of the cash transfer program. The findings from the study suggested a 36 percent raise in agricultural input spending for the average treatment effect estimate that is highly significant and can be traced to the cash transfer program. Additionally, after accounting for the selection bias, the average treatment effect on the treated estimates reveals a highly significant 18 percent increase in the input spending by the farmers. The results further suggest that the intervention shifts expenses away from imputed labour toward paid labour, and facilitates increased use of fertilizers.

detail.title: Designing a Cloud-Based Accounting Information System for Real-Time Financial Analysis
detail.abstract: The digitalization of financial procedures has revolutionized the analogue accounting and a transition to real time and cloudbased systems has made the financial transparency and decision making feasible. Based on the scalability and user-friendliness of an architectural platform "in the cloud," this study presents and assesses a prototype Cloud-Based Accounting Information System (CBAIS) that would help overcome the weaknesses of traditional ERP paradigms by including fundamental capabilities (such as management of an accounting ledger, ensuring transactions, tracking compliance) within a flexible cloud-Heuristicallyoriented and based on the three-tier model, the system was implemented on the AWS infrastructure and tested over the synthetic dataset, which mimicked 100 diverse transactions in accounting. Results showed a high accuracy of report generation with a range of deviation of about +-1% and low latency (average of 149.87 milliseconds) which is an indication that the system has the capability of handling real-time analysis of finance. The platform's dashboard interface made it easy to access the reports and visualizations in an intuitive manner, while the security measures such as AES-256 encryption and role-based access control ensured that the integrity of the data and auditability were guaranteed. This research helps underscore the possibilities of cloud-native AIS to provide outfits such as the small and medium-sized enterprises with cost-effective, scalable, and responsive means for financial oversight. The conclusion of the study provides recommendations for incorporating the live APIs and the AI-powered features in future cycles of development, with an additional emphasis on the necessity of real-world pilot testing to better understand the users' experience and the system's robustness.

detail.title: Inflation Targeting: An Emerging Issue and Nepalese Context
detail.abstract: Inflation targeting is a monetary policy regime. It involves the public announcement of medium-term numerical targets for inflation with an institutional commitment by the monetary authority to achieve these targets. Adoption of inflation targeting is not just a policy declaration. For that certain prerequisites must be fulfilled. Focusing monetary policy on inflation does not imply that inflation targeting is indifferent to the performance of the real economy is simply incorrect. In Nepalese context, to switch monetary policy towards inflation targeting, central bank should have to fulfill prerequisite first. Basically autonomy of central bank, public communication are the most important prerequisite that Nepal must have to fulfill. Top of all the existing exchange rate system with Indian currency must be addressed so that economy can move towards inflation targeting.

detail.abstract: Abhaya's fatal death at R.G. Kar Medical College triggered both public demonstrations for justice and discovered enduring institutional problems and daily unfairness inside medical facilities throughout West Bengal. Abhaya's' demise exposed an institutional environment which combines culture of threat and intimidation with systemic corruption in the medical colleges of the state. During the R.G. Kar uprising junior doctors demanded a transformation of institutional policies as well as workplace safety measures alongside a system of institutional oversight. Based on this evidence the article shows that recurring contentious actions against entrenched power structure show no capability to dismantle deep-rooted everyday injustice. The successful path to substantial change requires combining deliberative and dialogical practices which include dismissing daily injustices. Medical institutions that shift from protest responses toward cultural-functional changes can move toward accountable practices that provide equity. The pursuit of justice involves more than receiving compensation following disasters and punishing the guilty because it requires eradication of daily unjust practices before they turn into a tragedy like Abhaya.

title: Bridging or Blocking? How Digital Inclusive Finance Affects Firms’ Carbon Disclosure Pathways

detail.title: Bridging or Blocking? How Digital Inclusive Finance Affects Firms’ Carbon Disclosure Pathways
detail.abstract: Against the backdrop of global climate governance and China's dual-carbon targets, this study investigates the impact mechanism of Digital Inclusive Finance (DIF) on corporate carbon disclosure. Grounded in resource orchestration theory and based on panel data of A-share listed firms in China from 2011 to 2021, along with regional DIF index data, we conduct an empirical analysis. The results show that DIF significantly enhances corporate carbon disclosure. DIF simultaneously exerts a negative effect on firms' technology innovation, revealing a masking mediating effect where DIF promotes disclosure but partially offsets this benefit by suppressing internal technological advancement. In addition, firm size plays a positive moderating role in the relationship between DIF and innovation; larger firms are better able to integrate DIF-related resources and mitigate its inhibitory effect on innovation activities. Regional heterogeneity analysis further indicates that DIF significantly promotes carbon disclosure in eastern China. This study enriches the literature on digital finance and environmental information disclosure and provides theoretical insights and practical implications for improving corporate transparency and designing targeted policy interventions.

title: The Protection of Art and Cultural Heritage by Trademarks
affiliations: University of Lucerne

detail.title: The Protection of Art and Cultural Heritage by Trademarks
detail.abstract: Intellectual property (IP) protection is inherently related to creativity. Yet, the linkages between different IP forms and art and cultural heritage are by no means straightforward. This chapter focuses in particular on the toolbox of trademark law to map existing tensions and to explore to what extent trademarks offer useful, albeit imperfect ways, to protect cultural heritage and art. The chapter starts with a brief primer on trademark law (Section II) and then explores the possibilities it offers for the defensive and offensive protection of cultural heritage (Section III), and for art (Section IV). The following section (IV) offers a critical appraisal of the status quo and concludes the enquiry into the (mis)matches between trademark law and art and cultural heritage protection.

title: Understanding Digital Economy Agreements as a New Model of Trade Governance
affiliations: University of Lucerne, University of Lucerne and University of Lucerne

detail.title: Understanding Digital Economy Agreements as a New Model of Trade Governance
detail.abstract: Digital Economic Agreements (DEAs) represent a novel and increasingly influential instrument in the governance of digital trade. Departing from the broader and more traditional scope of Preferential Trade Agreements (PTAs), DEAs focus exclusively on digital trade, establishing dedicated regulatory frameworks for the data-driven economy. This article offers a detailed analysis of the architecture, substantive scope and underlying dynamics of DEAs. It maps the convergences and divergences among existing agreements, with particular attention paid to provisions on data governance and source code, situating DEAs within the broader landscape of PTAs' digital trade rulemaking. We further contrast the DEA model with the ongoing WTO negotiations towards an agreement on electronic commerce and examine the legal compatibility of DEAs with WTO law. We argue that DEAs represent a flexible and forward-oriented model for digital trade regulation. Nonetheless, their impact on the ground and whether they reduce or rather exacerbate the existing regulatory fragmentation in digital trade governance are questions that warrant further attention.

title: Escalating Priming by Arbuscular Mycorrhiza Against Tetranychus Urticae from Laboratory Conditions to Real Crop Production
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Escalating Priming by Arbuscular Mycorrhiza Against Tetranychus Urticae from Laboratory Conditions to Real Crop Production
detail.abstract: The two spotted spider mite Tetranychus urticae is a polyphagous pest that can adapt to hundreds of host plant species within few generations, causing important losses on relevant crops worldwide. Mycorrhizal symbiosis can improve plant resistance against diverse pests and pathogens in different plant species. Yet, the wider adoption of Mycorrhiza-Induced Resistance (MIR) in pest management is hindered by its high context-dependency. Here, we evaluate the efficacy of MIR in tomato against T. urticae performing multiple experiments, ranging from laboratory to real production conditions. We hypothesised that MIR would be functional to protect tomato plants against the mite from the lab to the field. MIR was observed under lab and semi-field conditions in artificial infestation bioassays. A dedicated metabolomic analysis revealed that MIR primed two phenylpropanoids, malic acid and a flavonoid. MIR and chemical treatments were escalated to real tomato production conditions. Plants inoculated with the mycorrhizal fungus Rhizophagus irregularis behaved resistant against T. urticae, strongly reducing the natural infestation of the spider mite. Similarly, the identified primed compounds caused a marked reduction in the incidence of the pest. Collectively, we show for the first time that MIR against T. urticae provides a consistent and strong protection in tomato in different culture scenarios, highlighting its context-stability in this pathosystem. MIR primes a specific fingerprint of secondary metabolites which enhance protection of tomato plants under real field conditions. We provide solid evidence supporting that MIR and MIR-related priming compounds could be valuable additions into IPM programs to improve tomato pest control.

title: Police & Thieves: An Equilibrium Spatial Model of Crime and Surveillance

detail.title: Police & Thieves: An Equilibrium Spatial Model of Crime and Surveillance
detail.abstract: This paper develops a game-theoretic model to study the spatial interplay between criminals, who decide whether and where to commit crimes, and the police, who chooses the enforcement level at its jurisdiction points. We assume that: crimes closer to police units are more likely to be cleared; criminals' decisions are based on the balance between local gains from crime and local punishment probabilities; and the police units are placed as a point process aiming to maximize the number of cleared crimes.We obtain that the crime rate and the police efficacy depend on the spatial distribution entropy of criminal opportunities. We find several counter-intuitive insights, such as: more punishment against a minority might increase the aggregate crime rate; more poverty might cause higher-income agents to commit crimes; and increasing income inequality might decrease the crime rate.These findings are beyond reach of models that abstract from the spatial dimension.

title: A Theoretical Foundation of Ambiguity Measurement: A Reply
affiliations: City University of New York, Baruch College - Zicklin School of Business - Department of Economics and Finance

detail.title: A Theoretical Foundation of Ambiguity Measurement: A Reply
detail.abstract: Fu, Melenberg, and Schweizer (FMS, 2023) revisits the ambiguity measure, ℧2, introduced in Izhakian (2020), and its underlying decision-theoretic models. This reply highlights four key fundamental incompatibilities of FMS’s framework with the models it aims to revisit, which render its conclusions invalid.(i) FMS reduces acts to lotteries, which is invalid when the preference relation is not probabilistically sophisticated; the preference relation in Izhakian (2020) is not probabilistically sophisticated.(ii) FMS violates the independence between outcome ranking (event outcomes) and event ranking (event probabilities), which is crucial in the axiomatic foundation of the underlying decision-theoretic models.(iii) FMS treats nonadditive probabilities (capacities) as if they were additive and Choquet integration as if it were Riemann integration, which is a fundamental inconsistency with the functional representation of preferences in the underlying decision-theoretic models.(iv) FMS relies upon an equivalence between first-order stochastic dominance (FOSD) and higher expected utility (monotonicity with respect to FOSD) to establish its main claim. An equivalence between conventional FOSD and higher expected utility does not exist (monotonicity with respect to FOSD is violated) when probabilities are nonadditive.The counter-examples in FMS implement these incompatibilities, violating the axioms of the underlying decision-theoretic models.

title: Reflecting on Reflective Loss
affiliations: National University of Singapore (NUS) - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Reflecting on Reflective Loss
detail.abstract: In Commonwealth jurisdictions, the reflective loss doctrine bars shareholders from recovering damages that overlap with the company's own losses. In this article, I locate the doctrine's theoretical foundations in liquidation protection-the rules that shield corporate assets from unilateral withdrawals, thereby facilitating capital lock-in and long-term investment. Although these rules offer clear benefits, they also carry costs, including the risk of controller opportunism. Drawing on a Law & Economics framework, I argue that, while the question of how best to tailor the rule to manage these trade-offs depends on empirical considerations, the notion that shareholders have voluntarily subordinated their claims to those of the company provides a robust response to these considerations, and in turn offers a strong justification for the existence of the doctrine. Nevertheless, I propose that factors such as the derivative action regime and conflict-of-interest constraints can help refine the rule's application. I also examine whether creditors should face a similar bar on overlapping losses, focusing on whether they voluntarily subordinate their claims in a manner analogous to shareholders. By engaging with recent legal developments, including Sevilleja v Marex Financial Ltd [2020] UKSC 31, I aim to provide a nuanced perspective on how liquidation protection shapes incentives under evolving reflective loss rules.

title: Private Plans, Public Goals: Preserving an Individual Market That Offsets the Employer Tax Advantage and Avoids Medicaid
affiliations: The Jack Kemp Foundation and DePaul University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Private Plans, Public Goals: Preserving an Individual Market That Offsets the Employer Tax Advantage and Avoids Medicaid
detail.abstract:
We identify three problems with the Affordable Care Act changes in the One Build Back Better Legislation that will undermine the functioning of the Individual Marketplace.

First, allowing enhanced credits and silver loading to lapse would raise net premiums roughly 75 percent for most subsidized households, a move that would deepen the employer-tax distortion already warping the market.

Second, tighter verification can curb improper enrollments, but coupling new paperwork with higher premiums would push four to six million eligible people out of Marketplace plans, trading limited fraud savings for a surge in un-insurance or Medicaid crowd-in.

Finally, the main impact of ending auto-re-enrollment, shortening sign-up windows, and adding a five dollar nominal monthly payment would be to deter healthier enrollees from enrolling, triggering predictable adverse selection yet still preferable to losing them entirely to the uninsured pool.

Today’s individual market, while imperfect, has achieved record insurer choice with only modest premium growth. This market could unravel if abrupt subsidy cuts force carriers to reprice sharply or exit. Subsidized Marketplace coverage, especially if bolstered by Custom Health Option and Individual Care Expense (CHOICE) employer contributions, remains the most market-aligned way to offset the far larger Employer-Sponsored Insurance tax break while preserving consumer choice and provider access.

title: Gradual Policy Reforms
affiliations: University of Aarhus - Department of Economics and Business Economics and Aarhus University - School of Business and Social Sciences

detail.title: Gradual Policy Reforms
detail.abstract: We investigate, using a theoretical framework and an online experiment, whether a gradual policy reform can increase support for socially desirable, but controversial policies compared to a one-step reform. Under a gradual reform, voters first decide on implementing an intermediate policy level, followed by a second decision between maintaining the intermediate level or adopting a higher level. We hypothesize that the gradual reform may increase voter support by shifting norms and correcting misperceptions about the effects of the policy; but it has the disadvantage that the benefits of a high policy level, relative to an intermediate level, can appear (too) small: voters are satisfied with the intermediate policy. Our empirical findings reveal that the gradual reform backfires: fewer voters support the high policy level under the gradual reform than under the one-step reform. This effect appears to stem from voter satisfaction with the intermediate policy level and from adverse responses to subsequent reform steps. Further, while experience indeed reduces misperceptions about the intermediate policy level, there is no spillover of this experience to perceptions of the high level. Information provision about descriptive norms partially alleviates backfiring of the gradual reform.

title: A Trade-Off between Monetary Policy Transmission and Systemic Risk in China
affiliations: Emory University - Department of Economics, Peking University and Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta

detail.title: A Trade-Off between Monetary Policy Transmission and Systemic Risk in China
detail.abstract:
We examine how interbank wholesale funding shapes the transmission of interest-rate-based monetary policy in China and contributes to systemic risk. Using a bank-level quarterly panel dataset and an estimated policy rule for the 7-day repo rate, we find that access to wholesale funding amplifies the transmission of monetary policy easing to lending by non-state banks, but also heightens their vulnerability to systemic risk during economic downturns. Since 2018, non-state banks with greater reliance on wholesale funding have experienced larger increases in expected capital shortfalls. To interpret these findings, we develop a structural model that incorporates a dual-track interest rate system and a segmented deposit market. The model quantifies the role of a liquidity reallocation channel from state to non-state banks and reveals a macroprudential trade-off: tighter regulation of wholesale funding weakens the effectiveness of monetary policy but mitigates systemic risk.
